Pathophysiology: Breast-conserving surgery (BCS) vs mastectomy decision depends on several factors: Contraindications to breast-conserving surgery: Factor Rationale Multicentric disease Tumors in different quadrants (>5 cm apart) Large tumor-to-breast ratio Cannot achieve negative margins with acceptable cosmesis Inability to achieve negative margins After reasonable re-excisions Prior breast radiation Cannot reirradiate Inflammatory breast cancer Requires mastectomy Diffuse suspicious microcalcifications Suggests extensive DCIS Pregnancy (relative) Radiation contraindicated; can delay if late pregnancy This patient: • Two invasive carcinomas in different quadrants (upper outer + lower inner) • 7 cm apart = multicentric disease • Multicentric disease = contraindication to BCS Why multicentric disease requires mastectomy: • BCS requires single surgical field with radiation to tumor bed • Multiple widely separated tumors cannot be encompassed by standard BCS + radiation • Higher local recurrence rates with BCS for multicentric disease  • A: Multiple lumpectomies for multicentric disease associated with high local recurrence; not standard of care • B: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy may shrink tumors but doesn't change multicentric anatomy; still requires mastectomy • D: Oncoplastic techniques don't overcome multicentricity; still separate tumor beds • E: Leaving untreated cancer is not appropriate  Multicentric breast cancer (tumors in different quadrants >5 cm apart) is a contraindication to breast-conserving surgery → mastectomy required. Multifocal (same quadrant) may still permit BCS.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Lumpectomy of both lesions with radiation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by reassessment: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Oncoplastic lumpectomy with bilateral reduction mammoplasty: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Lumpectomy of larger lesion only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Multifocal (same quadrant) may still permit BCS.

stem:
A 30-year-old G3P0020 at 18 weeks presents for routine ultrasound. Her obstetric history includes two second- trimester losses at 19 and 21 weeks—both presented with painless cervical dilation. Current transvaginal ultrasound shows cervical length of 2.8 cm with closed internal os. She has had no contractions, bleeding, or ROM.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Immediate cerclage placement based on obstetric history","label":"A"},{"text":"Serial cervical length monitoring; cerclage if length <25mm","label":"B"},{"text":"Vaginal progesterone supplementation only","label":"C"},{"text":"Reassurance; cervical length is normal","label":"D"},{"text":"Cerclage now plus vaginal progesterone","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Cerclage indications fall into three categories: Type Criteria Timing History-indicated ≥3 prior second-trimester losses OR prior preterm birth with cervical insufficiency 12–14 weeks (before cervical changes) Ultrasound-indicated Prior spontaneous PTB <34wk + current short cervix (<25mm) before 24wk When cervix shortens Rescue (physical exam– indicated) Dilated cervix with visible membranes Emergency This patient: • 2 prior second-trimester losses (classic cervical insufficiency history) • Does NOT meet history-indicated threshold (requires ≥3 losses or 1 loss with documented insufficiency) • Current cervix is 2.8 cm = normal length Management for patient with 1–2 prior losses suggestive of insufficiency but not meeting history-indicated criteria: • Serial transvaginal cervical length surveillance q2 weeks starting at 16 weeks • Ultrasound-indicated cerclage if cervix shortens to <25mm before 24 weeks • Vaginal progesterone if short cervix develops (can be used with or instead of cerclage)  • A: History-indicated cerclage requires ≥3 losses; this patient has 2 • C: Progesterone alone is reasonable for short cervix but cervix is currently normal; surveillance is priority • D: Given her history, she requires serial monitoring even with normal current length • E: No indication for cerclage with current cervical length of 28mm  History-indicated cerclage: ≥3 prior second-trimester losses. For 1–2 losses: serial cervical length monitoring with ultrasound-indicated cerclage if cervix shortens to <25mm before 24 weeks.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Immediate cerclage placement based on obstetric history: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Vaginal progesterone supplementation only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Reassurance; cervical length is normal: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Cerclage now plus vaginal progesterone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: For 1–2 losses: serial cervical length monitoring with ultrasound-indicated cerclage if cervix shortens to <25mm before 24 weeks.

stem:
An 18-month-old boy is evaluated for developmental concerns. He is not yet walking independently (pulls to stand), has no words (babbles), and does not point to request or show objects. He has no dysmorphic features. He was born at term with uncomplicated delivery. Hearing screen at birth was passed. There is no family history of developmental disorders. Physical exam including head circumference is normal.

What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
options: [{"text":"Brain MRI","label":"A"},{"text":"Chromosomal microarray","label":"B"},{"text":"Fragile X testing","label":"C"},{"text":"Metabolic panel including lactate, ammonia, and urine organic acids","label":"D"},{"text":"Electroencephalogram","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Global developmental delay (GDD) evaluation follows a tiered approach based on diagnostic yield: Definition of GDD: Significant delay (<2 SD) in ≥2 developmental domains in child <5 years Tiered workup: Tier Test Yield When to Order 1 Chromosomal microarray (CMA) 15–20% First-line for unexplained GDD 1 Fragile X (males) 2–3% First-line for males with GDD 2 Brain MRI 30% abnormal, but rarely changes management if CMA/FX negative Abnormal neuro exam, microcephaly, regression, seizures 2 Metabolic studies <1% in non-syndromic GDD Regression, episodic symptoms, consanguinity, organomegaly 3 Whole exome sequencing Variable After CMA/FX negative This patient: • Global developmental delay (motor, language, social) • No dysmorphic features, normal exam • No regression or episodic symptoms Chromosomal microarray is first-line because: • Highest diagnostic yield (~15–20%) for unexplained GDD • Detects copy number variants (deletions, duplications) missed by karyotype • Non-invasive (blood test) • Results guide prognosis and recurrence risk counseling  • A: MRI often abnormal but rarely diagnostic in non-syndromic GDD without focal findings; pursue after genetic testing • C: Fragile X testing appropriate for males but CMA should be sent simultaneously as it has higher overall yield • D: Metabolic workup has very low yield (<1%) without red flags (regression, consanguinity, organomegaly, acidosis) • E: EEG indicated for seizures or regression (Landau-Kleffner); not routine for GDD  Unexplained global developmental delay → chromosomal microarray first (15–20% yield). Add Fragile X testing for males. MRI and metabolic studies are second-tier for those with additional red flags.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Brain MRI: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Fragile X testing: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Metabolic panel including lactate, ammonia, and urine organi...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Electroencephalogram: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: MRI and metabolic studies are second-tier for those with additional red flags.

stem:
A 19-year-old woman with anorexia nervosa is brought by her parents for worsening restriction. She reports eating ~400 calories daily for the past month. BMI is 15.2 kg/m². Vitals: HR 42, BP 78/50, temperature 35.6°C. Labs: potassium 2.9 mEq/L, glucose 58 mg/dL, phosphorus 2.2 mg/dL. ECG shows sinus bradycardia with prolonged QTc (480 ms).

What is the most appropriate disposition?
options: [{"text":"Intensive outpatient program with daily monitoring","label":"A"},{"text":"Psychiatric hospitalization for supervised refeeding","label":"B"},{"text":"Medical hospitalization for cardiac and metabolic stabilization","label":"C"},{"text":"Residential eating disorder treatment facility","label":"D"},{"text":"Outpatient follow-up with dietitian within 1 week","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Anorexia nervosa hospitalization requires understanding medical vs psychiatric criteria: Medical hospitalization criteria (any ONE): Category Threshold Heart rate <50 bpm (this patient: 42) Blood pressure <80/50 or orthostatic (this patient: 78/50) Potassium <3.0 mEq/L (this patient: 2.9) Glucose <60 mg/dL (this patient: 58) Phosphorus <2.5 mg/dL (this patient: 2.2) QTc >450–460 ms (this patient: 480) Temperature <36°C (this patient: 35.6) BMI <14–15 kg/m² (varies by guideline) This patient has MULTIPLE medical hospitalization criteria: • HR 42 ✓ • BP 78/50 ✓ • K+ 2.9 ✓ • Glucose 58 ✓ • Phos 2.2 ✓ • QTc 480 ms ✓ • Temp 35.6°C ✓ Medical vs psychiatric hospitalization: • Medical floor: Cardiac monitoring, electrolyte repletion, supervised refeeding with refeeding syndrome precautions • Psychiatric unit: After medical stabilization; for patients who are medically stable but refuse treatment or have severe psychiatric comorbidity  • A: Intensive outpatient cannot manage medical instability • B: Psychiatric hospitalization is appropriate AFTER medical stabilization; this patient needs cardiac monitoring • D: Residential programs are for stable patients requiring long-term behavioral treatment • E: Medical instability precludes outpatient management  Anorexia nervosa with bradycardia (<50), hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities, or ECG changes = medical hospitalization first. Psychiatric hospitalization follows medical stabilization. BATCH 3 — QUESTION GENERATION COMPLETE Summary: • Neurology: 8 questions • OB/GYN: 8 questions • Pediatrics: 6 questions • Surgery: 7 questions • Psychiatry: 7 questions Total: 36 questions

Distractor Analysis: (A) Intensive outpatient program with daily monitoring: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Psychiatric hospitalization for supervised refeeding: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Residential eating disorder treatment facility: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Outpatient follow-up with dietitian within 1 week: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: BATCH 3 — QUESTION GENERATION COMPLETE Summary: • Neurology: 8 questions • OB/GYN: 8 questions • Pediatrics: 6 questions • Surgery: 7 questions • Psychiatry: 7 questions Total: 36 questions

stem:
A 29-year-old nulligravid woman presents with 2 years of progressive dysmenorrhea, deep dyspareunia, and dyschezia during menses. She is not currently trying to conceive but hopes to have children within 2–3 years. Pelvic exam reveals a fixed, retroverted uterus with nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a 3 cm left ovarian endometrioma.

What is the most appropriate management approach?
options: [{"text":"Combined oral contraceptives for symptom suppression","label":"A"},{"text":"GnRH agonist therapy for 6 months","label":"B"},{"text":"Diagnostic laparoscopy with excision of endometriosis","label":"C"},{"text":"Expectant management until she is ready to conceive","label":"D"},{"text":"Refer for in vitro fertilization","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Endometriosis management depends on symptom severity, fertility goals, and disease extent: Medical therapy indications: • Suspected endometriosis without endometrioma or deep infiltrating disease • Pain management when fertility not immediately desired • Post-surgical suppression Surgical therapy indications: • Endometrioma >3 cm — May impact ovarian reserve; cystectomy improves fertility and symptoms • Deep infiltrating endometriosis — Nodularity in cul-de-sac, rectovaginal involvement • Failed medical management • Definitive diagnosis needed • Fertility optimization — Surgery improves spontaneous conception rates in mild-moderate disease This patient: • Moderate-severe symptoms • Endometrioma (3 cm) • Deep infiltrating disease (cul-de-sac nodularity, dyschezia) • Desires future fertility Surgical excision is preferred because: 1. Endometrioma and deep disease respond poorly to medical therapy alone 2. Surgery improves fertility outcomes before conception attempts 3. Medical therapy only suppresses, doesn't treat; symptoms recur after stopping  • A: COCs may help pain but don't treat endometrioma or deep disease; delay definitive treatment • B: GnRH agonists cause hypoestrogenic side effects, don't shrink endometriomas significantly, and symptoms recur after stopping • D: Disease progression may worsen fertility; proactive treatment indicated • E: IVF is for conception, not treatment of symptomatic endometriosis; she's not trying to conceive yet  Endometrioma ≥3 cm or deep infiltrating endometriosis (especially with future fertility goals) → surgical excision.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Combined oral contraceptives for symptom suppression: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) GnRH agonist therapy for 6 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Expectant management until she is ready to conceive: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Refer for in vitro fertilization: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Medical therapy is for symptom suppression in mild disease or post-surgical maintenance.

stem:
A 10-month-old boy is evaluated for poor weight gain. His weight has dropped from the 25th percentile at 4 months to the 3rd percentile now, while length and head circumference remain at the 25th percentile. He was breastfed exclusively until 6 months, then started solids. Mother reports he is a "picky eater" and mealtimes are stressful. He has no vomiting, diarrhea, or respiratory symptoms. He reaches appropriately for food and has normal activity level. Physical exam is unremarkable except for decreased subcutaneous fat.

What is the most likely etiology of this patient's failure to thrive?
options: [{"text":"Celiac disease","label":"A"},{"text":"Cystic fibrosis","label":"B"},{"text":"Inadequate caloric intake","label":"C"},{"text":"Growth hormone deficiency","label":"D"},{"text":"Congenital heart disease","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Failure to thrive (FTT) evaluation hinges on distinguishing organic from nonorganic (psychosocial/nutritional) causes: Pattern recognition: Feature Organic FTT Nonorganic FTT Weight, length, HC All affected (or length/HC first) Weight affected first, length/HC preserved Symptoms Vomiting, diarrhea, respiratory, dysmorphism Usually absent Feeding behavior May have oral aversion, dysphagia Chaotic mealtimes, food refusal Activity May be decreased Normal Catch-up with adequate calories May not catch up Rapid catch-up This patient: • Weight declined while length/HC preserved → classic for inadequate intake • No GI symptoms (argues against celiac, CF) • Normal activity and development • Stressful mealtimes, "picky eater" → feeding behavior issues • Transition from breastfeeding to solids at 6 months correlates with weight decline Management of suspected inadequate intake: 1. Detailed feeding history (volume, frequency, preparation of formula, introduction of solids) 2. Observed feeding session 3. Caloric prescription and close follow-up 4.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Celiac disease: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Cystic fibrosis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Growth hormone deficiency: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Congenital heart disease: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Detailed feeding history and observed feeding are diagnostic.

stem:
A 20-month-old girl is brought to the ED after a 2-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure during a febrile illness (T 39.2°C). She returned to baseline within 20 minutes. This is her second simple febrile seizure—her first occurred at 13 months. Neurologic exam is normal. Family history is notable for the patient's mother having febrile seizures as a child.

What is the most appropriate counseling regarding seizure prophylaxis?
options: [{"text":"Start daily levetiracetam to prevent recurrence","label":"A"},{"text":"Prescribe rectal diazepam for use during future febrile illnesses","label":"B"},{"text":"Reassure that prophylaxis is not indicated for simple febrile seizures","label":"C"},{"text":"Start daily phenobarbital given recurrent seizures","label":"D"},{"text":"Obtain EEG before deciding on prophylaxis","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Simple febrile seizures are benign and do NOT require prophylactic antiepileptic medication, even with recurrence. Simple febrile seizure criteria: • Age 6 months to 5 years • Generalized seizure • Duration <15 minutes • Single seizure in 24 hours • Normal neurologic exam afterward • No prior afebrile seizures Key points for counseling: • Recurrence risk: ~30% after first seizure; higher with younger age, lower temperature at seizure, family history, short duration of fever before seizure • Epilepsy risk: NOT increased by simple febrile seizures (~1%, same as general population) • Prophylaxis: NOT recommended—AEDs have significant side effects (sedation, behavioral changes, hepatotoxicity) that outweigh benefit for a benign condition • Antipyretics: Do NOT prevent febrile seizures (fever is a marker, not the cause) Options for high-anxiety families (not standard of care): • Intermittent rectal or nasal diazepam at fever onset—reduces recurrence but has sedation risks; reserved for parental anxiety, not medical necessity  • A: Daily AEDs not indicated for simple febrile seizures regardless of recurrence • B: Intermittent diazepam is an option for parental anxiety but NOT standard recommendation; doesn't change long-term outcome • D: Phenobarbital has significant cognitive/behavioral side effects; risks far outweigh benefits • E: EEG not indicated for simple febrile seizures; findings don't change management and may cause unnecessary concern  Simple febrile seizures (even recurrent) do not require prophylaxis—reassure parents of benign prognosis. Daily AEDs and intermittent antipyretics do NOT prevent recurrence and carry risks exceeding benefits.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Start daily levetiracetam to prevent recurrence: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Prescribe rectal diazepam for use during future febrile illn...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Start daily phenobarbital given recurrent seizures: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Obtain EEG before deciding on prophylaxis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Daily AEDs and intermittent antipyretics do NOT prevent recurrence and carry risks exceeding benefits.

stem:
A 33-year-old G1P0 at 30 weeks with gestational diabetes has been on dietary modification for 2 weeks. Her fasting glucose logs show values of 98, 102, 95, 105, and 99 mg/dL over the past week. Two-hour postprandial values are consistently 115–125 mg/dL. She has gained 2 pounds since diagnosis. Fetal growth ultrasound is scheduled for 32 weeks.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Continue diet therapy; recheck in 2 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Add metformin for fasting hyperglycemia","label":"B"},{"text":"Initiate nighttime NPH insulin","label":"C"},{"text":"Initiate rapid-acting insulin with meals","label":"D"},{"text":"Increase dietary carbohydrate restriction","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: GDM glucose targets (Fifth International Workshop): • Fasting: <95 mg/dL (some use <90) • 1-hour postprandial: <140 mg/dL • 2-hour postprandial: <120 mg/dL This patient's values: • Fasting: 95–105 → Consistently elevated (4/5 values exceed 95) • Postprandial: 115–125 → At or slightly above 2-hour target When to escalate from diet to pharmacotherapy: • Fasting or postprandial targets not achieved after 1–2 weeks of diet/exercise • Majority of values out of range Choosing the agent: • Fasting hyperglycemia → Hepatic glucose production overnight → Nighttime NPH insulin (or long-acting insulin) • Postprandial hyperglycemia → Inadequate insulin response to meals → Rapid-acting insulin with meals or metformin • Both → Combination therapy This patient's primary issue is fasting glucose, so nighttime NPH addresses the pathophysiology (suppresses overnight hepatic gluconeogenesis). • A: Two weeks is adequate diet trial; persistent fasting elevation requires escalation • B: Metformin primarily lowers fasting glucose by reducing hepatic glucose output; however, insulin is first- line in GDM due to more predictable pharmacokinetics and established safety profile • D: Postprandial values are borderline/at target; prandial insulin addresses postprandial, not fasting glucose • E: Further carbohydrate restriction unlikely to address fasting glucose; may be inadequate nutrition  GDM with elevated fasting glucose despite diet → start nighttime NPH insulin. Elevated postprandial glucose → add prandial rapid-acting insulin or consider metformin (second-line).

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue diet therapy; recheck in 2 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Add metformin for fasting hyperglycemia: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Initiate rapid-acting insulin with meals: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Increase dietary carbohydrate restriction: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Elevated postprandial glucose → add prandial rapid-acting insulin or consider metformin (second-line).

stem:
A 28-year-old G1P0 at 10 weeks presents with severe nausea and vomiting for 3 weeks. She has lost 8% of pre- pregnancy weight and has 3+ ketonuria. Vitals: HR 108, BP 138/88. Labs show TSH 0.1 mIU/L, free T4 1.8 ng/dL (slightly elevated). She has not yet had an ultrasound.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Start methimazole for gestational hyperthyroidism","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain pelvic ultrasound before further management","label":"B"},{"text":"Initiate IV fluids and antiemetics; discharge when tolerating oral intake","label":"C"},{"text":"Check serum hCG level to guide imaging decision","label":"D"},{"text":"Obtain TSH receptor antibodies to differentiate Graves disease","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Hyperemesis gravidarum with hyperthyroidism in the first trimester requires ruling out gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), particularly complete molar pregnancy: Features suggesting molar pregnancy: • Hyperemesis — More severe than typical pregnancy (very high hCG) • Gestational hyperthyroidism — hCG cross-reacts with TSH receptor • Hypertension — Preeclampsia before 20 weeks (classic for molar pregnancy) • Uterine size > dates • Vaginal bleeding This patient has a concerning triad: 1. Severe hyperemesis (8% weight loss) 2. Hyperthyroidism (suppressed TSH, elevated T4) 3. Hypertension at 10 weeks — Should NOT occur in normal pregnancy this early Management priority: Pelvic ultrasound to evaluate for: • Viable intrauterine pregnancy • Molar pregnancy ("snowstorm" pattern, no fetal pole) • Size-dates discrepancy Gestational hyperthyroidism (from normal pregnancy) typically doesn't require treatment—it resolves as hCG declines.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Start methimazole for gestational hyperthyroidism: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Initiate IV fluids and antiemetics; discharge when toleratin...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Check serum hCG level to guide imaging decision: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Obtain TSH receptor antibodies to differentiate Graves disea...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: • A: Gestational hyperthyroidism doesn't require antithyroid drugs; more importantly, must rule out molar pregnancy first • C: Supportive care is appropriate for hyperemesis but doesn't address the concerning hypertension/hyperthyroidism combination • D: While very high hCG suggests molar pregnancy, ultrasound is the definitive diagnostic test • E: TSH receptor antibodies distinguish Graves from gestational hyperthyroidism, but the immediate concern is ruling out GTD  Hyperemesis + hyperthyroidism + early hypertension (before 20 weeks) = suspect molar pregnancy → obtain pelvic ultrasound immediately.

stem:
A 32-year-old woman with BMI 38 and idiopathic intracranial hypertension has been on maximum-dose acetazolamide (2g/day) for 4 months with dietary counseling. She reports persistent daily headaches. Ophthalmology exam shows stable moderate papilledema with visual field testing demonstrating enlarged blind spots and early peripheral field constriction—worse than 2 months ago. LP shows opening pressure of 38 cmH2O.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Add topiramate for adjunctive ICP lowering","label":"A"},{"text":"Continue current management and recheck in 2 months","label":"B"},{"text":"Refer for optic nerve sheath fenestration or CSF shunting","label":"C"},{"text":"Refer for bariatric surgery evaluation","label":"D"},{"text":"Perform serial therapeutic lumbar punctures","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: IIH management follows a stepwise approach with vision preservation as the primary goal: Step 1 — Conservative: • Weight loss (5–10% body weight can resolve IIH) • Acetazolamide (first-line medical therapy, up to 4g/day) Step 2 — Escalation indications: • Progressive visual field loss despite maximum medical therapy • Severe or rapidly progressive papilledema • Intractable headache with visual deterioration Step 3 — Surgical options: • Optic nerve sheath fenestration (ONSF) — Primarily for visual symptoms; less effective for headache • CSF diversion (VP or LP shunt) — For both visual and headache symptoms • Venous sinus stenting — If venous sinus stenosis present This patient has: • Maximum-dose acetazolamide (4 months) • Progressive visual field loss (primary concern) • Persistent elevated ICP Progressive visual field deterioration on maximum medical therapy = surgical intervention required. • A: Topiramate provides modest additional benefit but won't reverse progressive visual loss; delay risks permanent vision damage • B: Vision is worsening—cannot wait; permanent optic nerve damage is irreversible • D: Bariatric surgery is effective long-term but takes months for results; cannot wait with progressive visual loss • E: Serial LPs provide temporary relief but are not definitive; impractical for chronic management and don't prevent ongoing damage  IIH with progressive visual field loss despite maximum acetazolamide → surgical intervention (ONSF or shunt) is indicated to prevent permanent vision loss. Do not delay for weight loss or additional medical trials. OB/GYN

Distractor Analysis: (A) Add topiramate for adjunctive ICP lowering: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Continue current management and recheck in 2 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Refer for bariatric surgery evaluation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Perform serial therapeutic lumbar punctures: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Do not delay for weight loss or additional medical trials.

stem:
A 55-year-old man presents with a 6-cm reducible incisional hernia at his midline laparotomy scar from colectomy 2 years ago. The surgery was for perforated diverticulitis with gross fecal contamination. His BMI is 32. He is otherwise healthy with no current infection.

What is the most appropriate repair approach?
options: [{"text":"Primary suture repair without mesh","label":"A"},{"text":"Repair with synthetic mesh (polypropylene)","label":"B"},{"text":"Repair with biologic mesh","label":"C"},{"text":"Watchful waiting given contamination history","label":"D"},{"text":"Preoperative weight loss then synthetic mesh repair","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Incisional hernia repair considerations: Primary suture vs mesh: • Primary suture: Recurrence rate 30–50% • Mesh repair: Recurrence rate 10–15% • Recommendation: Mesh repair for all incisional hernias >2 cm Mesh selection based on wound classification: Wound Class Contamination Mesh Type Clean (Class I) None Synthetic mesh (polypropylene) Clean-contaminated (Class II) GI opened without spillage Synthetic (caution) or biologic Contaminated (Class III) Gross spillage, fresh trauma Biologic preferred Dirty (Class IV) Purulence, fecal contamination Biologic or delayed repair Key point: The wound classification at the TIME OF HERNIA REPAIR determines mesh choice, not the classification at original surgery. This patient: • Current presentation: Clean (Class I) — no infection, no contamination • History of contaminated surgery is irrelevant to current repair • 6-cm hernia → requires mesh (too large for primary repair) • Clean field → synthetic mesh appropriate Synthetic mesh is preferred in clean fields due to: • Lower cost • Better long-term durability • Equivalent infection rates to biologic in clean fields  • A: Primary repair has unacceptable recurrence rate for 6-cm hernia • C: Biologic mesh reserved for contaminated/infected fields; more expensive, less durable • D: Watchful waiting risks incarceration, enlargement; repair recommended for symptomatic hernias • E: While weight loss may reduce recurrence, no absolute BMI cutoff for repair; surgery shouldn't be indefinitely delayed  Incisional hernia mesh selection depends on contamination at time of REPAIR, not original surgery. Clean field → synthetic mesh. Contaminated/infected → biologic mesh.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Primary suture repair without mesh: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Repair with biologic mesh: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Watchful waiting given contamination history: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Preoperative weight loss then synthetic mesh repair: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Contaminated/infected → biologic mesh.

stem:
A 34-year-old G2P1 at 28 weeks has an ultrasound showing estimated fetal weight at the 5th percentile with normal amniotic fluid. Umbilical artery Doppler shows elevated S/D ratio but positive end-diastolic flow. Fetal anatomy and middle cerebral artery Doppler are normal. She has chronic hypertension on labetalol.

What is the most appropriate surveillance plan?
options: [{"text":"Weekly biophysical profile; deliver at 34 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Twice-weekly NST and weekly umbilical artery Doppler; deliver by 37 weeks","label":"B"},{"text":"Daily fetal kick counts; deliver at 39 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"Continuous inpatient monitoring until delivery","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat growth ultrasound in 4 weeks; routine prenatal care","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: IUGR (FGR) management depends on severity, Doppler findings, and gestational age: Classification by umbilical artery (UA) Doppler: UA Doppler Severity Surveillance Delivery Timing Normal Mild FGR Weekly NST; growth q3-4 weeks 38–39 weeks Elevated S/D, positive EDF Moderate Twice-weekly NST; weekly Dopplers 37 weeks Absent EDF (AEDF) Severe Daily NST or admission; steroids if <34wk 33–34 weeks Reversed EDF (REDF) Critical Inpatient; often deliver after steroids 30–32 weeks This fetus has: • EFW 5th percentile = FGR • Elevated S/D ratio but positive end-diastolic flow = moderate severity • 28 weeks = time to optimize with steroids before potential delivery Surveillance: Twice-weekly NST and weekly umbilical artery Doppler to detect progression to AEDF/REDF Delivery: By 37 weeks if stable; earlier if Dopplers worsen  • A: Weekly BPP alone is insufficient; UA Doppler progression guides management. Delivery at 34 weeks is premature for this stage • C: Too conservative; misses FGR severity. Kick counts alone inadequate for moderate FGR • D: Inpatient monitoring reserved for AEDF/REDF; not indicated for elevated S/D with positive EDF • E: Growth in 4 weeks is appropriate, but surveillance is insufficient given abnormal Doppler  FGR with elevated UA S/D ratio but positive EDF → twice-weekly NST + weekly Dopplers; deliver by 37 weeks. Absent or reversed EDF requires more intensive monitoring and earlier delivery.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Weekly biophysical profile; deliver at 34 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Daily fetal kick counts; deliver at 39 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Continuous inpatient monitoring until delivery: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Repeat growth ultrasound in 4 weeks; routine prenatal care: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Absent or reversed EDF requires more intensive monitoring and earlier delivery.

stem:
A 7-year-old girl with oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis affecting her left knee has been treated with naproxen and intra-articular corticosteroid injection 8 weeks ago. Despite initial improvement, she now has recurrent swelling and stiffness in the same knee with limited range of motion. Ophthalmologic exam is normal.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Repeat intra-articular corticosteroid injection","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to a different NSAID","label":"B"},{"text":"Initiate methotrexate","label":"C"},{"text":"Initiate etanercept (TNF inhibitor)","label":"D"},{"text":"Refer for synovectomy","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: JIA treatment follows a stepwise approach based on disease subtype and response: Oligoarticular JIA (≤4 joints): Step Therapy 1 NSAIDs + intra-articular corticosteroid (first-line) 2 DMARD (methotrexate) if inadequate response to above 3 Biologic (TNF inhibitor) if DMARD failure Indications to escalate to methotrexate: • Inadequate response to 2 months of NSAIDs • Recurrence after intra-articular injection • Functional limitation • High-risk features (uveitis risk, extended oligoarticular disease) This patient: • Failed NSAID + intra-articular steroid • Recurrent synovitis at 8 weeks (beyond typical 4–6 week response window) • Functional impairment (limited ROM) Methotrexate is the first DMARD used in JIA because: • Extensive efficacy and safety data in children • Weekly dosing (oral or subcutaneous) • Also protects against uveitis (important in oligoarticular JIA)  • A: Repeated injections into same joint without systemic therapy risks cartilage damage and is temporizing • B: NSAID switching rarely effective if first NSAID failed; doesn't address disease-modifying need • D: Biologics are reserved for DMARD failures; must trial methotrexate first per guidelines • E: Synovectomy is rarely indicated in modern era of effective medical therapy  JIA with inadequate response to NSAIDs + intra-articular steroids → initiate methotrexate. Biologics (TNF inhibitors) are second-line after DMARD failure.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Repeat intra-articular corticosteroid injection: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Switch to a different NSAID: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Initiate etanercept (TNF inhibitor): Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Refer for synovectomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Biologics (TNF inhibitors) are second-line after DMARD failure.

stem:
A 58-year-old man with bipolar disorder on lithium for 15 years presents with 1 week of progressive tremor, unsteady gait, and confusion. His family reports he's been vomiting from a "stomach bug" for 5 days and has been taking extra ibuprofen for back pain. He appears lethargic with coarse tremor and ataxia. Labs: lithium level 2.8 mEq/L (therapeutic 0.6–1.2), creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (baseline 1.0), and potassium 5.1 mEq/L.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"IV normal saline hydration alone","label":"A"},{"text":"Hold lithium and observe; repeat level in 12 hours","label":"B"},{"text":"Hemodialysis","label":"C"},{"text":"Activated charcoal","label":"D"},{"text":"IV sodium bicarbonate for alkaline diuresis","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Lithium toxicity classification and management: Types of lithium toxicity: Type Mechanism Level vs Symptoms Management Acute (overdose) Ingestion High level, mild symptoms initially GI decontamination; IVF; HD if severe Chronic Decreased clearance Moderate level, SEVERE symptoms HD often needed Acute-on-chronic Both Variable Based on symptoms This patient has CHRONIC lithium toxicity: • Gradual symptom onset (1 week) • Precipitants: Volume depletion (vomiting) + NSAIDs (ibuprofen inhibits renal lithium clearance) • Level 2.8 with severe CNS symptoms (confusion, ataxia) • AKI (Cr 2.1) Key principle: In chronic toxicity, lithium has equilibrated into tissues (especially brain). Even "moderate" levels (2– 2.5) can cause severe toxicity because CNS levels are high. Hemodialysis indications: • Level >4.0 (any toxicity type) • Level >2.5 with significant symptoms • Any level with severe neurologic symptoms (altered mental status, seizures, coma) • Renal impairment limiting clearance • Unable to tolerate fluids  • A: IVF helps in mild toxicity but insufficient for severe neurologic symptoms with AKI • B: Observation too conservative; CNS symptoms require intervention • D: Activated charcoal doesn't bind lithium; not helpful • E: Lithium is not amenable to alkaline diuresis (unlike salicylates)  Chronic lithium toxicity with neurologic symptoms (confusion, ataxia, tremor) → hemodialysis, even at moderate levels (2.5–3.5). Chronic toxicity causes severe symptoms at lower levels than acute toxicity due to CNS lithium accumulation.

Distractor Analysis: (A) IV normal saline hydration alone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Hold lithium and observe; repeat level in 12 hours: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Activated charcoal: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) IV sodium bicarbonate for alkaline diuresis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Chronic toxicity causes severe symptoms at lower levels than acute toxicity due to CNS lithium accumulation.

stem:
A 42-year-old woman with migraines (8–10 headache days/month) and BMI 34 requests preventive therapy. She also has hypertension controlled on lisinopril and reports depressed mood for which she declines antidepressant medication. She is concerned about weight gain. Prior trial of topiramate was stopped due to significant word- finding difficulty.

Which prophylactic agent is most appropriate for this patient?
options: [{"text":"Propranolol","label":"A"},{"text":"Amitriptyline","label":"B"},{"text":"Valproate","label":"C"},{"text":"Venlafaxine","label":"D"},{"text":"Onabotulinumtoxin A","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Migraine prophylaxis selection requires matching agent to comorbidities: Agent Benefits Avoid if Beta-blockers HTN, anxiety, tremor Asthma, depression (relative), bradycardia Topiramate Obesity (weight loss) Kidney stones, cognitive concerns Amitriptyline Insomnia, depression, tension-type overlap Obesity, cardiac conduction issues Valproate Bipolar, epilepsy Obesity, childbearing potential Venlafaxine Depression, anxiety HTN (can raise BP) CGRP inhibitors Failed ≥2 preventives Cost/access This patient: • Hypertension → beta-blocker provides dual benefit • Obesity → avoid valproate and amitriptyline (weight gain) • Topiramate intolerance → already failed • Declines antidepressants → rules out amitriptyline, venlafaxine • Does not meet criteria for onabotulinumtoxin A (requires ≥15 headache days/month for chronic migraine) Propranolol addresses HTN and provides first-line migraine prophylaxis without weight gain. • B: Causes weight gain; patient declined antidepressants • C: Significant weight gain; teratogenic (relevant for reproductive-age woman) • D: Patient declined antidepressants; can worsen hypertension • E: Only FDA-approved for chronic migraine (≥15 days/month); she has 8–10 days  Match migraine prophylaxis to comorbidities: beta-blocker for HTN; topiramate for obesity; amitriptyline for insomnia/depression; valproate for epilepsy (avoid in women of childbearing age); CGRP inhibitors after failing 2+ preventives.

Distractor Analysis: (B) Amitriptyline: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Valproate: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Venlafaxine: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Onabotulinumtoxin A: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: • B: Causes weight gain; patient declined antidepressants • C: Significant weight gain; teratogenic (relevant for reproductive-age woman) • D: Patient declined antidepressants; can worsen hypertension • E: Only FDA-approved for chronic migraine (≥15 days/month); she has 8–10 days  Match migraine prophylaxis to comorbidities: beta-blocker for HTN; topiramate for obesity; amitriptyline for insomnia/depression; valproate for epilepsy (avoid in women of childbearing age); CGRP inhibitors after failing 2+ preventives.

stem:
A 34-year-old woman with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis on natalizumab presents with worsening right leg weakness over 2 days. She reports low-grade fever and dysuria for the past 4 days. Her last relapse was 8 months ago. Examination shows 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity (baseline was 4+/5) and an MRI from 3 months ago showed stable lesion burden.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Administer IV methylprednisolone 1g daily for 3–5 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain urinalysis and urine culture before initiating steroids","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain MRI brain and spine with gadolinium","label":"C"},{"text":"Switch disease-modifying therapy due to breakthrough disease","label":"D"},{"text":"Reassure and observe with outpatient follow-up in 1 week","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This presentation is classic for pseudo-relapse—worsening of pre-existing neurologic deficits triggered by physiological stressor (here, UTI). Key distinguishing features: • Pseudo-relapse: Occurs with infection, fever, heat, or stress; symptoms are recurrence/worsening of OLD deficits; resolves when trigger treated; no new MRI lesions • True relapse: New or substantially worsened symptoms lasting >24 hours; typically new lesions on MRI; no identifiable trigger The dysuria and fever strongly suggest UTI as the culprit. Treatment of the underlying infection typically resolves neurologic worsening within 24–48 hours. Administering steroids before ruling out infection is inappropriate— steroids can worsen infection and won't address the underlying cause.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Administer IV methylprednisolone 1g daily for 3–5 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Obtain MRI brain and spine with gadolinium: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Switch disease-modifying therapy due to breakthrough disease: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Reassure and observe with outpatient follow-up in 1 week: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: • A: Premature—steroids should not be given until infection is excluded; treating UTI may resolve symptoms entirely • C: MRI is reasonable if infection workup is negative and symptoms persist, but not the immediate next step • D: No evidence of breakthrough disease—this appears triggered by infection, not DMT failure • E: Untreated UTI in MS patient risks worsening pseudo-relapse and systemic complications  Always rule out infection (especially UTI), fever, and metabolic derangements before diagnosing MS relapse— pseudo-relapse resolves with trigger treatment and does not require steroids.

stem:
A 62-year-old woman with myasthenia gravis on pyridostigmine 90mg every 4 hours presents with worsening dyspnea and generalized weakness over 2 days. She increased her pyridostigmine dose 3 days ago due to perceived symptom worsening. Vitals: HR 58, BP 110/70, RR 24, SpO2 91% on room air. Exam shows bilateral ptosis, proximal weakness, diffuse fasciculations, diaphoresis, and excessive salivation. Negative inspiratory force is -18 cmH2O.

What is the most appropriate immediate management?
options: [{"text":"Administer additional pyridostigmine","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer atropine and prepare for intubation","label":"B"},{"text":"Hold pyridostigmine and prepare for intubation","label":"C"},{"text":"Administer edrophonium as a diagnostic test","label":"D"},{"text":"Start IV immunoglobulin immediately","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has cholinergic crisis—excess acetylcholinesterase inhibitor causing both nicotinic and muscarinic toxicity: Feature Myasthenic Crisis Cholinergic Crisis Cause Undertreated MG Excess anticholinesterase Weakness Present Present Fasciculations Absent Present SLUDGE symptoms Absent Present (salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, GI upset, emesis) Bradycardia Absent Present Pupils Normal Miotic Response to edrophonium Improves Worsens Key findings indicating cholinergic crisis: • Recent pyridostigmine increase • Fasciculations (nicotinic excess) • SLUDGE: salivation, diaphoresis (muscarinic excess) • Bradycardia Management: 1. Stop anticholinesterase medications immediately 2. Airway protection — NIF < -20 to -25 indicates impending respiratory failure 3. Supportive care; atropine only if severe bradycardia or secretions compromising airway  • A: Would worsen cholinergic crisis catastrophically • B: Atropine addresses muscarinic symptoms but doesn't reverse nicotinic weakness; holding pyridostigmine is the priority • D: Edrophonium would worsen cholinergic crisis; contraindicated when cholinergic crisis suspected • E: IVIG treats myasthenic crisis, not cholinergic crisis; stopping the offending medication is first priority  Fasciculations + SLUDGE symptoms + bradycardia in MG patient on anticholinesterases = cholinergic crisis → stop pyridostigmine immediately and prepare for airway management.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Administer additional pyridostigmine: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Administer atropine and prepare for intubation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Administer edrophonium as a diagnostic test: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Start IV immunoglobulin immediately: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Supportive care; atropine only if severe bradycardia or secretions compromising airway  • A: Would worsen cholinergic crisis catastrophically • B: Atropine addresses muscarinic symptoms but doesn't reverse nicotinic weakness; holding pyridostigmine is the priority • D: Edrophonium would worsen cholinergic crisis; contraindicated when cholinergic crisis suspected • E: IVIG treats myasthenic crisis, not cholinergic crisis; stopping the offending medication is first priority  Fasciculations + SLUDGE symptoms + bradycardia in MG patient on anticholinesterases = cholinergic crisis → stop pyridostigmine immediately and prepare for airway management.

stem:
A 58-year-old man presents with 6 months of progressive numbness and burning in both feet. He has no diabetes (HbA1c 5.4%), drinks 1–2 beers weekly, and takes no medications. Examination reveals decreased pinprick and vibration sense to the mid-shin bilaterally with absent ankle reflexes. Initial labs show normal glucose, B12, TSH, and CBC.

What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
options: [{"text":"Nerve conduction studies and electromyography","label":"A"},{"text":"Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation","label":"B"},{"text":"Lumbar puncture with CSF analysis","label":"C"},{"text":"Genetic testing for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease","label":"D"},{"text":"Trial of gabapentin for symptomatic relief","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: When initial workup for peripheral neuropathy is unrevealing, systematic evaluation for treatable causes is essential. Tiered approach to cryptogenic neuropathy: Tier 1 (Initial): Glucose/HbA1c, B12, TSH, CBC, CMP — rules out the "big 3" (diabetes, B12 deficiency, hypothyroidism) — done and normal Tier 2 (Extended): • SPEP/immunofixation — screens for monoclonal gammopathy (MGUS, myeloma, amyloidosis, POEMS) • HIV, hepatitis B/C serologies • ANA, ESR (vasculitis, connective tissue disease) • Methylmalonic acid (functional B12 deficiency) Tier 3 (Specialized): NCS/EMG (characterizes neuropathy type), genetic testing, nerve biopsy, paraneoplastic antibodies Monoclonal gammopathy causes ~10% of initially idiopathic neuropathies and is treatable. • A: NCS/EMG characterizes neuropathy pattern but doesn't identify cause; appropriate after serologic workup • C: LP indicated if inflammatory/infectious etiology suspected (AIDP, CIDP); not routine for distal sensory neuropathy • D: CMT typically presents younger with foot deformities and family history; genetic testing is tier 3 • E: Symptomatic treatment before diagnosis may mask progression and delay identifying treatable cause  Idiopathic neuropathy with negative initial labs → check SPEP with immunofixation (monoclonal gammopathy is common and treatable), HIV, hepatitis serologies, and ANA before proceeding to electrodiagnostics.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Nerve conduction studies and electromyography: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Lumbar puncture with CSF analysis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Genetic testing for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Trial of gabapentin for symptomatic relief: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: SPEP with immunofixation (not just SPEP alone) is essential because immunofixation detects small monoclonal proteins missed by SPEP.

stem:
A 71-year-old man with Parkinson disease for 9 years on carbidopa-levodopa 25/100mg four times daily reports that his medications "wear off" about 1 hour before each dose. He also experiences involuntary writhing movements of his trunk and limbs during peak effect. His wife confirms the dyskinesias occur 1–2 hours after each dose.

Which adjustment best addresses both his wearing-off and peak-dose dyskinesia?
options: [{"text":"Increase each carbidopa-levodopa dose","label":"A"},{"text":"Add entacapone to each levodopa dose","label":"B"},{"text":"Give smaller, more frequent doses of carbidopa-levodopa","label":"C"},{"text":"Add amantadine","label":"D"},{"text":"Add pramipexole","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient demonstrates two common motor complications: 1. Wearing-off — Motor benefit wanes before next dose (predictable end-of-dose deterioration) 2. Peak-dose dyskinesia — Involuntary choreiform movements at time of peak levodopa levels The management strategy depends on which fluctuation predominates: Problem Strategy Wearing-off alone Add COMT inhibitor (entacapone), increase dose, add dopamine agonist, or shorten dosing interval Peak-dose dyskinesia alone Reduce individual doses, add amantadine Both wearing-off AND dyskinesia Smaller, more frequent doses (smooths plasma levels); add amantadine for dyskinesia Smaller, more frequent dosing reduces peak levels (↓ dyskinesia) while maintaining more consistent coverage (↓ wearing-off). This addresses both issues simultaneously.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Increase each carbidopa-levodopa dose: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Add entacapone to each levodopa dose: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Add amantadine: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Add pramipexole: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Amantadine is the specific add-on for refractory dyskinesia.

stem:
A 31-year-old woman with PCOS and BMI 27 presents with 14 months of infertility. She has 3–4 menses per year. Her partner's semen analysis is normal. HSG shows patent tubes. She has tried lifestyle modifications for 6 months without achieving spontaneous ovulation.

What is the first-line pharmacologic agent for ovulation induction?
options: [{"text":"Clomiphene citrate","label":"A"},{"text":"Letrozole","label":"B"},{"text":"Metformin","label":"C"},{"text":"Gonadotropins (FSH injections)","label":"D"},{"text":"Combined oral contraceptives to regulate cycles first","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Ovulation induction in PCOS follows a stepwise approach: Line Agent Notes First Letrozole Superior live birth and ovulation rates vs clomiphene in PCOS (PPCOS II trial); lower multiple gestation risk Second Clomiphene Alternative first-line; anti-estrogen at hypothalamus → ↑ GnRH/FSH Third Gonadotropins For clomiphene/letrozole failures; higher multiple gestation and OHSS risk Third Laparoscopic ovarian drilling Alternative to gonadotropins Line Agent Notes Third IVF For failed ovulation induction or other factors Letrozole vs Clomiphene: • Letrozole: Aromatase inhibitor → ↓ estrogen → ↑ FSH; thinner endometrial lining is NOT an issue (unlike clomiphene); fewer multiples • Clomiphene: Anti-estrogen → blocks negative feedback → ↑ GnRH/FSH; can cause hostile cervical mucus and thin endometrium The landmark PPCOS II trial (2014) established letrozole as superior to clomiphene for PCOS ovulation induction: • Higher ovulation rate • Higher live birth rate (27.5% vs 19.1%) • Lower multiple gestation rate  • A: Clomiphene is an acceptable alternative but no longer first-line per current evidence • C: Metformin improves ovulation rates but is inferior to letrozole/clomiphene for conception; adjunctive role • D: Gonadotropins are second/third-line due to higher risk profile • E: OCPs regulate cycles but prevent pregnancy; not indicated when actively trying to conceive  First-line ovulation induction for PCOS = letrozole (PPCOS II trial). Clomiphene is second-line. Gonadotropins for refractory cases. Pediatrics

Distractor Analysis: (A) Clomiphene citrate: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Metformin: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Gonadotropins (FSH injections): Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Combined oral contraceptives to regulate cycles first: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Gonadotropins for refractory cases.

stem:
A 3-year-old girl presents with her first febrile UTI. Urine culture grows >100,000 CFU/mL of E. coli. She is treated with oral antibiotics with clinical improvement. Renal bladder ultrasound shows normal kidneys bilaterally with no hydronephrosis or bladder abnormalities.

What is the most appropriate next step regarding imaging?
options: [{"text":"Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) to evaluate for vesicoureteral reflux","label":"A"},{"text":"DMSA renal scan to assess for scarring","label":"B"},{"text":"No additional imaging indicated","label":"C"},{"text":"Repeat renal ultrasound in 6 months","label":"D"},{"text":"CT urogram for detailed anatomical evaluation","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Pediatric UTI imaging strategy has evolved to reduce unnecessary invasive testing (AAP 2011, reaffirmed): After first febrile UTI (age 2–24 months): • Renal bladder ultrasound (RBUS): Recommended for ALL children with first febrile UTI • VCUG: NOT routine for first febrile UTI if RBUS is normal VCUG indications after first UTI: • Abnormal RBUS (hydronephrosis, scarring, other anomalies) • Recurrent febrile UTI • Atypical UTI course (poor response to appropriate antibiotics, unusual organism) • Family history of high-grade VUR • Clinical concern for posterior urethral valves (males with poor stream) This patient: • First febrile UTI • Normal RBUS • Good clinical response • No atypical features VUR is common (30–40% of children with UTI) but: • Most cases are low-grade and resolve spontaneously • Antibiotic prophylaxis for low-grade VUR has questionable benefit • VCUG is invasive (catheterization, radiation) The "top-down" approach: RBUS screens for significant anomalies; VCUG reserved for those with abnormalities or recurrence. • A: VCUG not indicated with normal ultrasound after first UTI—exposes child to catheterization and radiation without clear benefit • B: DMSA indicated if concern for scarring (recurrent UTI, atypical course); not routine after first UTI with normal ultrasound • D: Repeat ultrasound not needed if initial study was normal and child responded well • E: CT exposes child to significant radiation; never first-line in pediatrics  First febrile UTI + normal renal ultrasound = no VCUG needed. VCUG indicated for abnormal ultrasound, recurrent UTI, or atypical course. Surgery

Distractor Analysis: (A) Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) to evaluate for vesicoureter...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) DMSA renal scan to assess for scarring: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Repeat renal ultrasound in 6 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) CT urogram for detailed anatomical evaluation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: VCUG indicated for abnormal ultrasound, recurrent UTI, or atypical course.

stem:
A 48-year-old woman is post-operative day 3 after laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. She develops worsening right upper quadrant pain, fever to 38.4°C, and nausea. Her drain (placed intraoperatively due to inflamed gallbladder bed) output has increased to 200 mL of bilious fluid over 24 hours. Labs show WBC 14,000 and total bilirubin 2.8 mg/dL.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Return to operating room for exploratory laparotomy","label":"A"},{"text":"ERCP with sphincterotomy and possible stent placement","label":"B"},{"text":"CT abdomen with IV contrast","label":"C"},{"text":"Remove drain and observe","label":"D"},{"text":"HIDA scan to confirm bile leak","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Post-cholecystectomy bile leak is a recognized complication occurring in 0.3–0.5% of cases. Management depends on leak source and severity: Bile leak sources: • Cystic duct stump — Most common; usually low-grade • Duct of Luschka — Small duct from liver bed • Common bile duct injury — Most severe; requires surgical repair Management algorithm: Scenario Management Controlled leak with drain in place ERCP with sphincterotomy ± stent (first-line) Uncontrolled leak / biloma without drain CT-guided drainage + ERCP Major CBD injury (transection/ligation) Surgical repair (hepaticojejunostomy) Why ERCP is first-line for most bile leaks: 1. Sphincterotomy reduces sphincter of Oddi pressure, redirecting bile flow to duodenum 2. Stent placement further reduces pressure gradient across the leak 3.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Return to operating room for exploratory laparotomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) CT abdomen with IV contrast: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Remove drain and observe: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) HIDA scan to confirm bile leak: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Surgery only for major CBD injury or ERCP failure.

stem:
A 67-year-old woman underwent open sigmoid colectomy for colon cancer 5 days ago. She had return of bowel function (flatus) on post-operative day 3 and was tolerating a regular diet until this morning when she developed nausea, vomiting, and abdominal distension. She reports intermittent crampy abdominal pain. Exam shows distended abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds. She passed flatus this morning.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: [{"text":"Prolonged postoperative ileus","label":"A"},{"text":"Anastomotic leak","label":"B"},{"text":"Early postoperative small bowel obstruction","label":"C"},{"text":"Ogilvie syndrome (colonic pseudo-obstruction)","label":"D"},{"text":"Clostridium difficile colitis","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Distinguishing ileus from early postoperative SBO is crucial: Feature Postoperative Ileus Early SBO Timing POD 0–3; no prior return of function After initial return of function Pain Mild, constant discomfort Crampy, intermittent Bowel sounds Absent or hypoactive High-pitched, hyperactive Passage of flatus Absent May be present (partial) Course Gradually improves Worsens without intervention This patient: • Initial return of function (flatus POD 3, tolerating diet) — ileus had resolved • New symptoms after resolution — concerning for mechanical obstruction • Crampy pain — suggests peristalsis against obstruction • High-pitched bowel sounds — classic for SBO • Continued flatus — partial obstruction Early postoperative SBO (within 30 days): • Occurs in ~1% of abdominal surgeries • Causes: adhesions (most common), internal hernia, kinking at anastomosis • Management: NGT decompression, CT to evaluate; most resolve non-operatively initially  • A: Ileus doesn't present with crampy pain and hyperactive bowel sounds; typically no return of function • B: Anastomotic leak presents with fever, peritonitis, tachycardia; not typically obstructive symptoms • D: Ogilvie syndrome affects colon (massive colonic dilation); presents with distension but not crampy pain or high-pitched sounds • E: C. diff presents with watery diarrhea, fever, leukocytosis; not obstruction pattern  Crampy pain + high-pitched bowel sounds + symptoms AFTER initial return of bowel function = early postoperative SBO, not prolonged ileus. Ileus has absent/hypoactive sounds and no prior return of function.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Prolonged postoperative ileus: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Anastomotic leak: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Ogilvie syndrome (colonic pseudo-obstruction): Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Clostridium difficile colitis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Ileus has absent/hypoactive sounds and no prior return of function.

stem:
A 29-year-old G2P1 at 31 weeks gestation presents with rupture of membranes confirmed by pooling, ferning, and positive AmniSure. She is afebrile with reassuring fetal heart tracing and no contractions. GBS status is unknown. She received her first dose of betamethasone 6 hours ago.

What is the most appropriate management plan?
options: [{"text":"Proceed with delivery given confirmed rupture of membranes","label":"A"},{"text":"Expectant management with antibiotics until 34 weeks or complications develop","label":"B"},{"text":"Expectant management until 37 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"Administer tocolytics for 48 hours, then induce at 32 weeks","label":"D"},{"text":"Perform amniocentesis to assess fetal lung maturity before deciding","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: PPROM (preterm prelabor rupture of membranes) management depends on gestational age: GA Management <23 weeks Counsel on options (expectant vs termination); high morbidity 23–34 weeks Expectant management with latency antibiotics until 34 weeks or complications 34–37 weeks Current evidence supports delivery at 34 weeks (some centers extend to 36-37) ≥37 weeks Deliver Components of expectant management at 31 weeks: 1. Corticosteroids — Complete course (2 doses, 24h apart) 2. Latency antibiotics — Ampicillin + azithromycin (7-day course) to prolong latency and reduce chorioamnionitis 3. GBS prophylaxis — If unknown status, treat as positive during labor 4.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Proceed with delivery given confirmed rupture of membranes: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Expectant management until 37 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Administer tocolytics for 48 hours, then induce at 32 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Perform amniocentesis to assess fetal lung maturity before d...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Deliver immediately if signs of infection, non-reassuring fetal status, or abruption.

stem:
A 28-year-old man with well-controlled focal epilepsy on levetiracetam 1500mg twice daily presents after a witnessed seizure this morning—his first in 2 years. He denies missed doses and his pill count confirms adherence. He started a new job last week with irregular sleep and reports taking over-the-counter diphenhydramine for insomnia. Vitals and neurologic exam are normal. Levetiracetam level is 18 mcg/mL (therapeutic: 12–46 mcg/mL).

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Increase levetiracetam to 2000mg twice daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Add a second antiepileptic drug","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain EEG and MRI brain","label":"C"},{"text":"Counsel on sleep hygiene and discontinue diphenhydramine","label":"D"},{"text":"Check CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Breakthrough seizures in adherent patients with therapeutic drug levels require identification of modifiable triggers before escalating therapy. This patient has two clear precipitants: 1. Sleep deprivation — Most common seizure trigger; lowers seizure threshold significantly 2. Diphenhydramine — Antihistamines lower seizure threshold and should be avoided in epilepsy The approach to breakthrough seizure in compliant patient: 1.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Increase levetiracetam to 2000mg twice daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Add a second antiepileptic drug: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Obtain EEG and MRI brain: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Check CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Common culprits: sleep deprivation, alcohol, medication interactions (fluoroquinolones, tramadol, bupropion, antihistamines), and illness.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman is post-operative day 1 after total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma. She reports perioral tingling and finger numbness. Labs show calcium 7.6 mg/dL and intact PTH 8 pg/mL (normal 15–65). She has no prior calcium supplementation.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Oral calcium carbonate 500mg three times daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Oral calcium carbonate plus calcitriol","label":"B"},{"text":"IV calcium gluconate bolus followed by oral calcium","label":"C"},{"text":"Observation with repeat calcium in 6 hours","label":"D"},{"text":"Magnesium replacement before calcium supplementation","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia results from parathyroid injury (transient stunning or inadvertent removal): Severity assessment: • Mild: Asymptomatic or perioral paresthesias; Ca 7.5–8.0 mg/dL • Moderate: Symptomatic paresthesias; Ca 7.0–7.5 mg/dL • Severe: Carpopedal spasm, tetany, arrhythmia; Ca <7.0 mg/dL Management by severity: Severity Management Symptomatic (any level) Oral calcium + calcitriol Severe (Ca <7.0 or severe symptoms) IV calcium gluconate → oral calcium + calcitriol Asymptomatic Oral calcium alone may suffice Why calcitriol (1,25-OH vitamin D)? • PTH normally stimulates 1α-hydroxylase to convert 25-OH vitamin D → active 1,25-OH vitamin D • With low PTH, this conversion is impaired • Calcitriol provides the active form, allowing calcium absorption • Without calcitriol, oral calcium alone is poorly absorbed This patient: • Symptomatic (paresthesias) • Low PTH (8 pg/mL) — confirms hypoparathyroidism • Moderate hypocalcemia (7.6 mg/dL)  • A: Calcium alone insufficient when PTH is low—needs calcitriol for adequate absorption • C: IV calcium reserved for severe/life-threatening symptoms (tetany, seizure, arrhythmia); this patient has mild symptoms • D: Patient is symptomatic—requires treatment, not observation • E: Magnesium should be checked but hypomagnesemia is not the likely cause post-thyroidectomy; parathyroid injury is  Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia with low PTH = oral calcium PLUS calcitriol (active vitamin D). Calcitriol compensates for impaired 1α-hydroxylation due to PTH deficiency.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Oral calcium carbonate 500mg three times daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) IV calcium gluconate bolus followed by oral calcium: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Observation with repeat calcium in 6 hours: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Magnesium replacement before calcium supplementation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Calcitriol compensates for impaired 1α-hydroxylation due to PTH deficiency.

stem:
A 67-year-old man presented 3 days ago with transient left arm weakness lasting 30 minutes. MRI showed a small acute infarct in the right corona radiata. ABCD2 score was 5. He was started on aspirin 81mg plus clopidogrel 75mg. Carotid imaging shows <50% stenosis bilaterally. Echocardiogram and telemetry show no cardioembolic source. He now asks how long he needs to take both medications.

What is the appropriate duration of dual antiplatelet therapy for this patient?
options: [{"text":"21 days, then aspirin monotherapy","label":"A"},{"text":"90 days, then aspirin monotherapy","label":"B"},{"text":"12 months, then reassess","label":"C"},{"text":"Indefinitely, given high-risk features","label":"D"},{"text":"Discontinue clopidogrel now; aspirin alone is sufficient","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: The POINT and CHANCE trials established dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) for high-risk TIA/minor stroke: Indications for DAPT: • High-risk TIA (ABCD2 ≥4) OR minor ischemic stroke (NIHSS ≤3) • Non-cardioembolic mechanism • Initiated within 24 hours of symptom onset Duration: • 21 days of aspirin + clopidogrel (CHANCE protocol, preferred) • Alternative: 21–30 days (some guidelines extend to 30) • NOT 90 days — POINT trial showed increased bleeding without additional benefit beyond 21–30 days • After DAPT: Continue aspirin monotherapy indefinitely This patient has minor stroke (DWI+ TIA = minor stroke by definition), ABCD2 of 5 (high-risk), and non- cardioembolic etiology—perfect candidate for 21-day DAPT. • B: 90 days showed excess bleeding in POINT trial without additional stroke reduction; 21 days is current standard • C: No indication for 12-month DAPT in stroke (unlike coronary stenting) • D: Indefinite DAPT increases bleeding; long-term management is aspirin monotherapy • E: Stopping clopidogrel at day 3 loses the early high-risk window benefit  High-risk TIA or minor stroke → 21 days of aspirin + clopidogrel (start within 24 hours) → then aspirin monotherapy lifelong. Do not extend DAPT beyond 21–30 days due to bleeding risk.

Distractor Analysis: (B) 90 days, then aspirin monotherapy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) 12 months, then reassess: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Indefinitely, given high-risk features: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Discontinue clopidogrel now; aspirin alone is sufficient: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Do not extend DAPT beyond 21–30 days due to bleeding risk.

stem:
A 48-year-old woman with major depressive disorder has failed adequate trials of sertraline (200mg x 10 weeks) and venlafaxine (225mg x 8 weeks) with minimal improvement. She has no history of mania, psychosis, or substance use. She asks about options beyond switching to another antidepressant.

Which augmentation strategy has the strongest evidence for treatment-resistant depression?
options: [{"text":"Add lithium","label":"A"},{"text":"Add buspirone","label":"B"},{"text":"Add modafinil","label":"C"},{"text":"Add atypical antipsychotic (aripiprazole)","label":"D"},{"text":"Add thyroid hormone (T3)","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is defined as failure of ≥2 adequate antidepressant trials. Options include: Evidence-based augmentation strategies: Agent Evidence Level Notes Atypical antipsychotics Strongest (FDA-approved) Aripiprazole, quetiapine, olanzapine/fluoxetine Lithium Strong (older studies) Requires monitoring; smaller effect in modern trials Thyroid hormone (T3) Moderate 25–50 mcg; better for T3 than T4 Bupropion Moderate Combination rather than augmentation Buspirone Weak-moderate Less robust data Atypical antipsychotics are currently first-line for TRD augmentation because: • FDA-approved: Aripiprazole (Abilify), quetiapine XR (Seroquel XR), olanzapine/fluoxetine (Symbyax), brexpiprazole (Rexulti) • Consistent efficacy in large RCTs • Aripiprazole has favorable metabolic profile among atypicals Lithium augmentation: • Well-established in older literature • Modern meta-analyses show smaller effect sizes than initially reported • Requires level monitoring, renal/thyroid function checks • Reserved for patients who also need mood stabilization or have suicidality (lithium reduces suicide risk)  • A: Lithium has evidence but is no longer first-line given monitoring burden and smaller modern effect sizes • B: Buspirone augmentation has weaker evidence than atypicals • C: Modafinil may help fatigue/concentration but limited antidepressant augmentation data • E: T3 augmentation has moderate evidence but atypicals have stronger, more consistent data  Treatment-resistant depression augmentation: first-line = atypical antipsychotic (aripiprazole or quetiapine). Lithium and T3 are alternatives with moderate evidence.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Add lithium: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Add buspirone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Add modafinil: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Add thyroid hormone (T3): Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Lithium and T3 are alternatives with moderate evidence.

stem:
A 41-year-old woman is admitted with acute pancreatitis secondary to gallstones. On hospital day 2, she has mild epigastric tenderness, lipase of 890 U/L (down from 2,400 U/L on admission), and no nausea or vomiting. She reports feeling hungry. She has been receiving IV fluids and IV morphine for pain control. CT performed on admission showed interstitial edematous pancreatitis without necrosis. She remains afebrile with stable vital signs.

What is the most appropriate nutritional management?
options: [{"text":"Continue NPO status until lipase normalizes","label":"A"},{"text":"Initiate nasojejunal tube feeding","label":"B"},{"text":"Start a clear liquid diet and advance as tolerated","label":"C"},{"text":"Delay oral intake until abdominal pain completely resolves","label":"D"},{"text":"Begin total parenteral nutrition","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Current evidence supports early oral feeding (within 24-48 hours) in acute pancreatitis when patients can tolerate it, regardless of lipase levels or mild residual pain. The traditional teaching of prolonged NPO status ("pancreatic rest") until complete pain resolution and lipase normalization has been disproven. Early enteral feeding maintains gut barrier function, reduces infectious complications, decreases length of stay, and may reduce mortality. This patient is hungry, has no nausea/vomiting, has mild uncomplicated (interstitial) pancreatitis, and has improving clinical status—all favorable indicators for initiating oral intake.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue NPO status until lipase normalizes: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Initiate nasojejunal tube feeding: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Delay oral intake until abdominal pain completely resolves: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Begin total parenteral nutrition: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: NEPHROLOGY

stem:
A 58-year-old woman undergoes CT abdomen for evaluation of kidney stones. Incidentally, a 0.9-cm homogeneous adrenal nodule is discovered with Hounsfield units of 8 (consistent with lipid-rich adenoma). She is normotensive, has no cushingoid features, and has no symptoms of hyperaldosteronism or catecholamine excess. She has no personal or family history of malignancy.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"24-hour urine catecholamines and metanephrines","label":"A"},{"text":"1-mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test","label":"B"},{"text":"Plasma aldosterone-to-renin ratio","label":"C"},{"text":"Complete hormonal workup including all of the above","label":"D"},{"text":"No further workup indicated","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Adrenal incidentalomas <1 cm with benign imaging characteristics (low Hounsfield units indicating lipid-rich content, homogeneous appearance, smooth borders) have extremely low malignant potential and low rates of hormonal hypersecretion. Current guidelines suggest that nodules <1 cm with imaging features consistent with adenoma do not require routine biochemical workup or follow-up imaging. The risk of clinically significant disease is negligible, and the cost and patient anxiety of testing outweigh potential benefits. This contrasts with lesions ≥1 cm, which typically warrant biochemical evaluation regardless of imaging appearance.

Distractor Analysis: (A) 24-hour urine catecholamines and metanephrines: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) 1-mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Plasma aldosterone-to-renin ratio: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Complete hormonal workup including all of the above: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: HEMATOLOGY/ONCOLOGY

stem:
A 58-year-old man with a 2-year history of persistent atrial fibrillation managed with metoprolol and apixaban presents with 6 weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. He denies chest pain or palpitations. Echocardiogram reveals a new finding of left ventricular ejection fraction of 38% (previously 55% one year ago), moderate mitral regurgitation, and left atrial enlargement. His ventricular rate is well-controlled at 78 bpm. NT-proBNP is elevated at 2,400 pg/mL. He has no history of coronary artery disease, and recent coronary angiography was unremarkable.

What is the most appropriate change to his atrial fibrillation management?
options: [{"text":"Continue current rate control with metoprolol","label":"A"},{"text":"Add digoxin for enhanced rate control","label":"B"},{"text":"Refer for catheter ablation with goal of rhythm control","label":"C"},{"text":"Initiate amiodarone for pharmacologic cardioversion","label":"D"},{"text":"Increase metoprolol dose to achieve resting rate below 60 bpm","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has tachycardia-mediated cardiomyopathy (or AFib-related cardiomyopathy), where persistent atrial fibrillation has led to new-onset heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Despite "adequate" rate control by traditional metrics, the loss of atrial kick and irregularity of AFib contributes to ventricular dysfunction. In this setting, the discovery of new HFrEF fundamentally changes the treatment paradigm from rate control to rhythm control. Catheter ablation for AFib in patients with HFrEF has been shown to improve ejection fraction, reduce hospitalizations, and decrease mortality compared to continued rate control.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue current rate control with metoprolol: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Add digoxin for enhanced rate control: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Initiate amiodarone for pharmacologic cardioversion: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Increase metoprolol dose to achieve resting rate below 60 bp...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: New-onset heart failure with reduced EF in a patient with atrial fibrillation should prompt a shift from rate control to rhythm control, preferably via catheter ablation.

stem:
A 68-year-old man with CKD stage 3b (baseline creatinine 2.1 mg/dL), heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and type 2 diabetes is hospitalized for acute kidney injury in the setting of volume depletion from gastroenteritis. His lisinopril was held on admission. Creatinine peaked at 3.8 mg/dL and has now recovered to 2.3 mg/dL after IV fluid resuscitation. His blood pressure is 128/78 mmHg. He is preparing for discharge.
