Prior to this hospitalization, his creatinine had been stable on lisinopril for 3 years with good BP control and no hyperkalemia.

What is the most appropriate management of his lisinopril at discharge?
options: [{"text":"Permanently discontinue lisinopril due to AKI","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to an ARB which has better renal safety","label":"B"},{"text":"Restart lisinopril at the prior dose once creatinine returns to baseline","label":"C"},{"text":"Restart lisinopril at a reduced dose with creatinine monitoring in 1 week","label":"D"},{"text":"Delay lisinopril restart for 3 months to allow renal recovery","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: ACE inhibitors provide significant long-term cardiorenal protection in patients with HFrEF and diabetic nephropathy. Temporary discontinuation during AKI is appropriate, but permanent discontinuation based solely on a hemodynamic/pre-renal AKI episode is not indicated. The AKI in this case was clearly precipitated by volume depletion, not intrinsic ACE inhibitor nephrotoxicity. Once the reversible trigger has resolved and creatinine is trending toward baseline, the ACE inhibitor should be restarted—often at a reduced dose initially—with close monitoring.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Permanently discontinue lisinopril due to AKI: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Switch to an ARB which has better renal safety: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Restart lisinopril at the prior dose once creatinine returns...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Delay lisinopril restart for 3 months to allow renal recover...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: ACE inhibitors held during pre-renal AKI should be restarted (often at reduced dose with monitoring) once the precipitant resolves; permanent discontinuation forfeits cardiorenal benefits.

stem:
A 35-year-old man was treated 8 weeks ago for uncomplicated acute appendicitis managed non-operatively with IV antibiotics due to his preference to avoid surgery. CT at that time showed a non-perforated appendix without abscess. He completed a 7-day antibiotic course with complete resolution of symptoms. Follow-up CT shows resolution of inflammation with a normal-appearing appendix. He remains asymptomatic.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Proceed with interval appendectomy within the next 4 weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Perform colonoscopy before deciding on surgery","label":"B"},{"text":"Interval appendectomy is not required; continue observation","label":"C"},{"text":"Obtain MRI of the abdomen before interval appendectomy","label":"D"},{"text":"Interval appendectomy only if symptoms recur","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: The management of uncomplicated appendicitis has evolved. Non-operative management with antibiotics is successful in 70-80% of patients, and of those, approximately 30-40% will have recurrence within 5 years. The traditional approach of interval appendectomy for all patients has been questioned. Current evidence suggests that routine interval appendectomy is not mandatory after successful non-operative treatment of uncomplicated appendicitis.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Proceed with interval appendectomy within the next 4 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Perform colonoscopy before deciding on surgery: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Interval appendectomy is not required; continue observation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Obtain MRI of the abdomen before interval appendectomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: BATCH 4 — QUESTION GENERATION COMPLETE Total questions generated: 33 Format: NBME-style clinical vignettes with single best answer Coverage: All 33 locked Batch 4 concepts

stem:
A 28-year-old woman with well-controlled asthma on medium-dose inhaled corticosteroid plus long-acting beta-agonist (ICS-LABA) had her therapy stepped down to low-dose ICS alone 6 weeks ago after 3 months of complete symptom control. She now presents with nighttime awakenings twice weekly and uses her rescue albuterol 4 times per week. She denies respiratory infection, new environmental exposures, or medication non-adherence. Peak flow is 75% of her personal best.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Restart medium-dose ICS-LABA and continue indefinitely","label":"A"},{"text":"Restart medium-dose ICS-LABA and reassess step-down eligibility in 3 months","label":"B"},{"text":"Increase to high-dose ICS monotherapy","label":"C"},{"text":"Add oral montelukast to current low-dose ICS","label":"D"},{"text":"Prescribe a short course of oral prednisone","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient's symptoms represent failure of step-down therapy rather than a true exacerbation. The appropriate response is to return to the previously effective regimen (medium-dose ICS-LABA) and reassess step-down eligibility after re-establishing control for at least 3 months. Failed step-down does not mean permanent therapy escalation—it means the patient was not ready for de-escalation at that time. After regaining control, another step-down attempt may be successful, particularly if modifiable factors (allergen exposure, technique, adherence) are optimized.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Restart medium-dose ICS-LABA and continue indefinitely: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Increase to high-dose ICS monotherapy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Add oral montelukast to current low-dose ICS: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Prescribe a short course of oral prednisone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: GASTROENTEROLOGY

stem:
A 7-month-old infant presents with 3 days of rhinorrhea, cough, and wheezing. She has mild tachypnea and scattered wheezes with adequate oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. She is feeding well, taking about 70% of her usual intake. RSV rapid antigen test is positive. The parents ask about nebulized treatments they read about online that can "clear the mucus."

What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding nebulized hypertonic saline?
options: [{"text":"Prescribe nebulized 3% hypertonic saline for home use","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer nebulized hypertonic saline in the emergency department and discharge","label":"B"},{"text":"Admit for nebulized hypertonic saline therapy","label":"C"},{"text":"Nebulized hypertonic saline is not indicated for this patient","label":"D"},{"text":"Use nebulized normal saline as a safer alternative","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This infant has mild bronchiolitis with adequate oxygen saturation and feeding. AAP guidelines recommend supportive care (hydration, nasal suctioning, oxygen if needed) as the mainstay of bronchiolitis management. Nebulized hypertonic saline is not recommended for infants treated in the emergency department or outpatient setting. While some evidence suggests modest benefit in reducing length of stay for hospitalized patients (likely through improved mucociliary clearance), this benefit does not apply to outpatients.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Prescribe nebulized 3% hypertonic saline for home use: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Administer nebulized hypertonic saline in the emergency depa...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Admit for nebulized hypertonic saline therapy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Use nebulized normal saline as a safer alternative: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Nebulized hypertonic saline may have modest benefit in hospitalized bronchiolitis patients but is not indicated in the emergency department or outpatient settings.

stem:
A 71-year-old woman with a history of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) 4 months ago (treated with oral vancomycin with resolution) presents with 5 days of watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fever. She completed a course of ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection 2 weeks ago. Stool PCR for C. difficile toxin is positive. She has 6-8 loose stools daily, WBC is 11,200/μL, and creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL. She is hemodynamically stable and tolerating oral intake.

What is the most appropriate treatment?
options: [{"text":"Oral vancomycin 125 mg four times daily for 10 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Oral fidaxomicin 200 mg twice daily for 10 days","label":"B"},{"text":"Oral vancomycin tapered and pulsed regimen over 6 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"Fecal microbiota transplantation","label":"D"},{"text":"Oral metronidazole 500 mg three times daily for 10 days","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has a first recurrence of CDI, which fundamentally changes the treatment approach. For first recurrence, fidaxomicin is preferred over standard-course vancomycin because it has demonstrated lower rates of subsequent recurrence. Fidaxomicin has a narrower spectrum with minimal disruption of the gut microbiome and achieves high fecal concentrations with sustained post-antibiotic effect against C. difficile spores.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Oral vancomycin 125 mg four times daily for 10 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Oral vancomycin tapered and pulsed regimen over 6 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Fecal microbiota transplantation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Oral metronidazole 500 mg three times daily for 10 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: difficile infection, fidaxomicin is the preferred treatment over standard vancomycin due to lower subsequent recurrence rates.

stem:
A 48-year-old woman is hospitalized with mild acute gallstone pancreatitis (Ranson score 1, no organ failure, CT shows interstitial edematous pancreatitis). By hospital day 3, her abdominal pain has resolved, she is tolerating a regular diet, and labs show lipase 180 U/L (down from 1,800 U/L), WBC 7,500/μL, and normal liver enzymes. Right upper quadrant ultrasound shows multiple gallstones with a normal common bile duct.

What is the most appropriate timing for cholecystectomy?
options: [{"text":"After 6 weeks to allow inflammation to resolve","label":"A"},{"text":"During this hospitalization before discharge","label":"B"},{"text":"Schedule electively within 2-4 weeks after discharge","label":"C"},{"text":"Only if recurrent pancreatitis occurs","label":"D"},{"text":"Perform ERCP with sphincterotomy instead of cholecystectomy","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: For mild gallstone pancreatitis without necrosis or other complications, cholecystectomy should be performed during the index hospitalization (same- admission cholecystectomy) once the patient has clinically recovered. This approach reduces the risk of recurrent biliary events, including recurrent pancreatitis (which occurs in 25-30% of patients within 6 weeks if cholecystectomy is delayed). Waiting 6 weeks was previously standard but has been shown to result in preventable recurrent events. Same-admission cholecystectomy is safe once pain resolves, diet is tolerated, and inflammatory markers are improving.

Distractor Analysis: (A) After 6 weeks to allow inflammation to resolve: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Schedule electively within 2-4 weeks after discharge: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Only if recurrent pancreatitis occurs: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Perform ERCP with sphincterotomy instead of cholecystectomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Cholecystectomy for mild gallstone pancreatitis should be performed during the same hospitalization once the patient has clinically recovered, not delayed for weeks.

stem:
A 67-year-old man with GOLD stage III COPD presents with 4 days of increased dyspnea and cough. He reports his sputum volume has increased but remains white-gray in color, similar to his baseline. He denies fever, chills, or chest pain. Vital signs show temperature 37.1°C, RR 22/min, SpO2 89% on room air (baseline 92%). Lung exam reveals diffuse expiratory wheezes without focal consolidation. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation without infiltrate. He uses tiotropium and a fluticasone/salmeterol inhaler daily.

What is the most appropriate antibiotic management?
options: [{"text":"Azithromycin 500 mg daily for 3 days","label":"A"},{"text":"Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg twice daily for 5 days","label":"B"},{"text":"Levofloxacin 750 mg daily for 5 days","label":"C"},{"text":"Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 7 days","label":"D"},{"text":"No antibiotics indicated at this time","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has a COPD exacerbation with only one Anthonisen criterion (increased dyspnea) without purulent sputum or significantly increased sputum volume beyond baseline. According to the Anthonisen classification, antibiotics are indicated for Type I exacerbations (all three cardinal symptoms: increased dyspnea, increased sputum volume, and sputum purulence) or Type II exacerbations if purulence is one of the two symptoms present. Sputum purulence is the strongest predictor of bacterial infection and antibiotic benefit. This patient has non-purulent sputum, making antibiotic therapy unlikely to provide benefit and exposing him to unnecessary side effects and resistance development.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Azithromycin 500 mg daily for 3 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg twice daily for 5 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Levofloxacin 750 mg daily for 5 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 7 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: In COPD exacerbations, sputum purulence is the critical Anthonisen criterion driving antibiotic use; increased dyspnea and non-purulent sputum alone do not warrant antibiotics.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman with major depressive disorder has been on sertraline 200 mg daily (maximum dose) for 10 weeks. She reports some improvement—her sleep is better, and she no longer has passive suicidal ideation—but continues to have low energy, anhedonia, and poor concentration that impair her work function. PHQ-9 score has decreased from 22 to 14. She tolerates the medication well with no significant side effects.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Continue sertraline monotherapy and reassess in 4 more weeks","label":"A"},{"text":"Switch to a different SSRI","label":"B"},{"text":"Augment with aripiprazole","label":"C"},{"text":"Switch to venlafaxine","label":"D"},{"text":"Discontinue sertraline and start psychotherapy alone","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has a partial response to adequate SSRI therapy (maximum dose, adequate duration of 10 weeks). A partial response is defined as some improvement but with persistent clinically significant symptoms. In this scenario, augmentation is preferred over switching because the patient has shown benefit from the current medication. Switching would abandon gains and restart the clock on response.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue sertraline monotherapy and reassess in 4 more weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Switch to a different SSRI: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Switch to venlafaxine: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Discontinue sertraline and start psychotherapy alone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: For partial SSRI response (some improvement but residual symptoms), augment with a second agent rather than switching medications.

stem:
A 24-year-old man with type 1 diabetes presents with altered mental status, Kussmaul respirations, and severe abdominal pain. Labs reveal glucose 580 mg/dL, pH 6.92, bicarbonate 4 mEq/L, anion gap 32, and potassium 2.9 mEq/L. He is hypotensive with BP 78/50 mmHg and tachycardic at 128 bpm. IV fluid resuscitation is initiated. Initial potassium replacement is started, but his pH continues to drop, and he is becoming increasingly obtunded.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Continue aggressive potassium replacement before starting insulin","label":"A"},{"text":"Start insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour immediately","label":"B"},{"text":"Administer sodium bicarbonate bolus","label":"C"},{"text":"Wait until potassium reaches 3.3 mEq/L before starting insulin","label":"D"},{"text":"Intubate for airway protection before any other intervention","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: The traditional teaching is to withhold insulin until potassium is ≥3.3 mEq/L because insulin drives potassium intracellularly and can precipitate fatal arrhythmias. However, in severe life-threatening acidosis (pH <7.0) with hemodynamic instability and altered mental status, the immediate threat is the acidosis itself. In this scenario, insulin should be started without delay while aggressively replacing potassium simultaneously. The rationale is that untreated severe acidosis will lead to death before hypokalemia can be corrected.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue aggressive potassium replacement before starting in...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Administer sodium bicarbonate bolus: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Wait until potassium reaches 3.3 mEq/L before starting insul...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Intubate for airway protection before any other intervention: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: In DKA with life-threatening acidosis (pH <7.0), start insulin immediately despite K+ <3.3 mEq/L while aggressively replacing potassium simultaneously.

stem:
A 26-year-old woman with a 6-week ectopic pregnancy (β-hCG 2,800 mIU/mL, adnexal mass 2.5 cm, no fetal cardiac activity, hemodynamically stable) received single-dose methotrexate (50 mg/m²) 7 days ago. Day 4 β-hCG was 3,100 mIU/mL and day 7 β-hCG is 2,950 mIU/mL (5% decline from day 4). She has mild abdominal discomfort but no rebound or guarding. Hemoglobin is stable at 11.8 g/dL.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Administer second dose of methotrexate","label":"A"},{"text":"Proceed to surgical management","label":"B"},{"text":"Check β-hCG in 1 week and continue observation","label":"C"},{"text":"Repeat methotrexate only if β-hCG rises above 3,500 mIU/mL","label":"D"},{"text":"Discharge with close outpatient follow-up","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Methotrexate treatment success is assessed by comparing day 4 and day 7 β-hCG levels. A decline of ≥15% from day 4 to day 7 indicates adequate response. This patient had only a 5% decline (3,100 to 2,950), which is technically insufficient by the 15% threshold. However, any decline (even if <15%) warrants continued observation with weekly β-hCG monitoring rather than immediate second dose or surgery, as many patients with slow initial decline will ultimately respond.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Administer second dose of methotrexate: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Proceed to surgical management: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Repeat methotrexate only if β-hCG rises above 3,500 mIU/mL: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Discharge with close outpatient follow-up: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: PEDIATRICS

stem:
An 18-month-old girl with no prior seizure history is brought in after having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure at home lasting approximately 20 minutes. She has had fever for 2 days with rhinorrhea and cough. On arrival, she is postictal and then has a second brief generalized seizure. Temperature is 39.5°C. After the seizure stops, she gradually becomes more alert but has left-sided weakness noted on exam. She is up to date on vaccinations including Hib and pneumococcal conjugate.

What is the most appropriate diagnostic evaluation?
options: [{"text":"Reassurance and discharge with return precautions","label":"A"},{"text":"EEG only","label":"B"},{"text":"Lumbar puncture and neuroimaging","label":"C"},{"text":"Lumbar puncture only","label":"D"},{"text":"Neuroimaging only","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This child has a complex febrile seizure with multiple concerning features: duration >15 minutes, multiple seizures within 24 hours, and focal postictal findings (Todd's paralysis). Complex febrile seizures, particularly with focal features, warrant additional evaluation to exclude serious underlying pathology. Lumbar puncture should be performed to evaluate for meningitis/encephalitis given the age, prolonged seizure, and focal findings. Neuroimaging (CT or MRI) is indicated due to the focal postictal deficit (Todd's paralysis) and prolonged seizure, which raise concern for structural abnormality, focal encephalitis (HSV), or complicated CNS infection.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Reassurance and discharge with return precautions: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) EEG only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Lumbar puncture only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Neuroimaging only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: SURGERY

stem:
A 34-year-old G1P0 woman at 30 weeks gestation was diagnosed with gestational diabetes at 26 weeks. After diet and exercise failed to achieve glycemic targets, glyburide 5 mg twice daily was initiated 3 weeks ago and titrated to 10 mg twice daily. Her fasting glucose remains 115-125 mg/dL (goal <95), and postprandial values are 160-180 mg/dL (goal <120 at 2 hours). She is adherent to medication and dietary recommendations. Fetal growth is at the 75th percentile.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Increase glyburide to 15 mg twice daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Add metformin to glyburide","label":"B"},{"text":"Switch to insulin therapy","label":"C"},{"text":"Continue current regimen as values are near target","label":"D"},{"text":"Recommend increased exercise and stricter diet","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has failed glyburide therapy for gestational diabetes. Oral agent failure is defined as inability to achieve glycemic targets despite maximum or near-maximum dosing with adequate adherence. Glyburide's maximum effective dose in pregnancy is typically 10-20 mg daily, and this patient is at 20 mg daily with persistently elevated fasting and postprandial glucoses. • A (Increase glyburide): At or near maximum dose; further increase has diminishing returns and increased hypoglycemia risk.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Increase glyburide to 15 mg twice daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Add metformin to glyburide: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Continue current regimen as values are near target: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Recommend increased exercise and stricter diet: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Failure to achieve glycemic targets on maximum oral agent therapy in gestational diabetes mandates transition to insulin, not addition of another oral agent.

stem:
A 56-year-old man with gout has been on allopurinol 300 mg daily for 6 weeks, started after his second gout flare. He now presents with acute onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling of his left first metatarsophalangeal joint. He was not prescribed prophylaxis at the time of allopurinol initiation. Uric acid level 2 weeks ago was 5.2 mg/dL (down from 9.8 mg/dL). Joint aspiration confirms negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals.

What is the most appropriate management of his allopurinol during this acute flare?
options: [{"text":"Discontinue allopurinol until the flare resolves","label":"A"},{"text":"Reduce allopurinol dose to 100 mg daily during the flare","label":"B"},{"text":"Continue allopurinol at current dose","label":"C"},{"text":"Increase allopurinol to 400 mg daily to lower uric acid further","label":"D"},{"text":"Switch to febuxostat for better uric acid control","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: When a gout flare occurs in a patient already on urate-lowering therapy (ULT), the ULT should be continued at the same dose, not stopped or adjusted. Historically, there was concern that continuing allopurinol would prolong flares, but evidence shows that discontinuing ULT during a flare leads to uric acid fluctuations that may worsen or prolong the attack. The flare should be treated with appropriate anti-inflammatory therapy (NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids), while allopurinol is maintained. Flares during ULT initiation are expected and reflect crystal mobilization as deposits dissolve—this is why prophylactic anti-inflammatory coverage should have been prescribed at initiation.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Discontinue allopurinol until the flare resolves: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Reduce allopurinol dose to 100 mg daily during the flare: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Increase allopurinol to 400 mg daily to lower uric acid furt...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Switch to febuxostat for better uric acid control: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Do not stop or adjust urate-lowering therapy during an acute gout flare; continue the current regimen and treat the flare with anti-inflammatory medications.

stem:
A 62-year-old man with compensated cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis C (SVR achieved 4 years ago) undergoes routine HCC surveillance. Ultrasound performed by an experienced technician shows a 1.5-cm hypoechoic lesion in the right hepatic lobe not seen on prior imaging 6 months ago. AFP level is 8 ng/mL (normal <10). He is asymptomatic with Child-Pugh class A cirrhosis. Prior surveillance ultrasounds were unremarkable.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Repeat ultrasound in 3 months","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain multiphasic CT or MRI of the liver","label":"B"},{"text":"Obtain AFP-L3 and des-gamma-carboxyprothrombin levels","label":"C"},{"text":"Proceed directly to percutaneous biopsy","label":"D"},{"text":"Continue routine surveillance with ultrasound in 6 months","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has a new liver lesion detected on surveillance ultrasound in the setting of cirrhosis, which raises concern for hepatocellular carcinoma regardless of AFP level. AFP has limited sensitivity (~60%) for HCC detection, meaning 40% of HCCs are AFP-negative. The appropriate next step is multiphasic contrast-enhanced CT or MRI to characterize the lesion. These modalities can diagnose HCC non-invasively if the lesion demonstrates characteristic arterial enhancement with washout in the portal venous or delayed phases.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Repeat ultrasound in 3 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Obtain AFP-L3 and des-gamma-carboxyprothrombin levels: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Proceed directly to percutaneous biopsy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Continue routine surveillance with ultrasound in 6 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: A new liver lesion on surveillance ultrasound in cirrhosis requires multiphasic CT or MRI regardless of AFP level; normal AFP does not exclude HCC.

stem:
A 74-year-old woman with hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (EF 58%) presents with progressive lower extremity edema and dyspnea on exertion over the past 3 weeks. She has been adherent to her furosemide 80 mg twice daily but reports minimal urine output despite the medication. Her weight has increased 4 kg since her last visit. Vital signs show BP 148/88 mmHg, HR 72 bpm. Labs reveal sodium 134 mEq/L, potassium 3.6 mEq/L, creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.2), and BNP 680 pg/mL. Physical exam confirms 3+ pitting edema bilaterally and bibasilar crackles.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Increase furosemide to 120 mg twice daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Add metolazone 2.5 mg daily","label":"B"},{"text":"Switch furosemide to bumetanide","label":"C"},{"text":"Add spironolactone 25 mg daily","label":"D"},{"text":"Initiate continuous furosemide infusion","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient demonstrates loop diuretic resistance, a common phenomenon in HFpEF where chronic loop diuretic use leads to distal nephron hypertrophy and compensatory sodium reabsorption. The clinical clues—adequate loop diuretic dosing, poor response, and volume overload—indicate the need for sequential nephron blockade. Adding a thiazide-type diuretic (metolazone) to the existing loop diuretic blocks sodium reabsorption at the distal convoluted tubule, overcoming the resistance mechanism. This synergistic approach is more effective than simply increasing the loop diuretic dose, which often yields diminishing returns.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Increase furosemide to 120 mg twice daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Switch furosemide to bumetanide: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Add spironolactone 25 mg daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Initiate continuous furosemide infusion: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: When a patient on adequate loop diuretic dosing shows persistent volume overload, add a thiazide (metolazone) for sequential nephron blockade rather than escalating the loop diuretic dose.

stem:
A 72-year-old man hospitalized after hip fracture surgery develops acute thrombocytopenia on postoperative day 7. Platelet count dropped from 180,000/μL to 58,000/μL. He has no bleeding but develops unilateral leg swelling. Duplex ultrasound confirms new deep vein thrombosis in the operated limb. Heparin is discontinued, and HIT antibody testing is sent. His creatinine is 3.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.4 mg/dL), indicating acute kidney injury likely secondary to contrast from imaging studies.

What is the most appropriate anticoagulant?
options: [{"text":"Fondaparinux 7.5 mg subcutaneous daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Argatroban continuous IV infusion","label":"B"},{"text":"Bivalirudin continuous IV infusion","label":"C"},{"text":"Rivaroxaban 15 mg twice daily","label":"D"},{"text":"Warfarin with INR target 2-3","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has probable heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) with thrombosis (HITT) requiring immediate alternative anticoagulation. The choice of agent depends critically on renal function. Fondaparinux, while effective in HIT, is renally eliminated and contraindicated or requires dose adjustment in significant renal impairment (CrCl <30 mL/min). This patient's acute kidney injury makes fondaparinux a poor choice.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Fondaparinux 7.5 mg subcutaneous daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Bivalirudin continuous IV infusion: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Rivaroxaban 15 mg twice daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Warfarin with INR target 2-3: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: In heparin-induced thrombocytopenia with renal impairment, argatroban (hepatically metabolized) is preferred over fondaparinux (renally eliminated).

stem:
A 78-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and COPD (FEV1 55% predicted) is found to have a reducible right inguinal hernia on routine physical exam. He has no symptoms—no pain, discomfort, or bulge awareness—and the hernia was discovered incidentally. He has a normal BMI and remains active with daily walks. He has no history of hernia complications.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Elective open hernia repair with mesh","label":"A"},{"text":"Elective laparoscopic hernia repair","label":"B"},{"text":"Watchful waiting with surgery if symptoms develop","label":"C"},{"text":"Truss fitting to prevent incarceration","label":"D"},{"text":"Urgent surgical referral due to incarceration risk","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Watchful waiting is an acceptable management strategy for asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic inguinal hernias, particularly in older patients or those with significant comorbidities. The WART trial (Watchful Waiting vs Repair Trial) demonstrated that in men with minimally symptomatic inguinal hernias, observation was safe, with low rates of hernia-related emergencies (1-2% per year) and crossover to surgery (about 20-25% at 2-4 years, usually for developing symptoms). For this elderly patient with COPD who has no symptoms, the surgical risk may outweigh the benefit of prophylactic repair. Surgery becomes indicated when symptoms develop.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Elective open hernia repair with mesh: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Elective laparoscopic hernia repair: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Truss fitting to prevent incarceration: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Urgent surgical referral due to incarceration risk: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Asymptomatic inguinal hernia in an elderly patient with comorbidities can be managed with watchful waiting; elective repair is not mandatory and is offered when symptoms develop.

stem:
A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks gestation is found to have an estimated fetal weight below the 3rd percentile with elevated umbilical artery Doppler pulsatility index (>95th percentile) but positive end-diastolic flow. Amniotic fluid index is 6 cm (low-normal). Detailed anatomic survey and genetic testing were normal. She has chronic hypertension controlled on labetalol. Biophysical profile is 8/8. Middle cerebral artery Doppler shows brain- sparing effect.

What is the most appropriate delivery timing if fetal status remains stable?
options: [{"text":"Deliver immediately due to IUGR severity","label":"A"},{"text":"Deliver at 34 weeks after antenatal corticosteroids","label":"B"},{"text":"Deliver at 37 weeks","label":"C"},{"text":"Deliver at 39 weeks","label":"D"},{"text":"Allow spontaneous labor regardless of gestational age","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This is early-onset fetal growth restriction (FGR), defined by onset before 32 weeks with abnormal umbilical artery Doppler. Early-onset FGR has different pathophysiology and management than late-onset FGR (>32 weeks). The presence of abnormal umbilical artery Doppler with brain-sparing (MCA redistribution) indicates placental insufficiency. For early-onset FGR with abnormal Doppler but preserved end-diastolic flow and reassuring biophysical profile, delivery is typically recommended around 34-37 weeks after antenatal corticosteroids, with closer timing (34 weeks) for more severe Doppler abnormalities or additional risk factors.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Deliver immediately due to IUGR severity: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Deliver at 37 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Deliver at 39 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Allow spontaneous labor regardless of gestational age: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Early-onset FGR (<32 weeks) with abnormal umbilical artery Doppler warrants earlier delivery (around 34 weeks with stable fetus) compared to late-onset FGR, which can be managed closer to term.

stem:
A 4-year-old boy was diagnosed with Kawasaki disease and received IVIG (2 g/kg) plus aspirin 5 days ago. His fever resolved for 48 hours but has returned, with temperature now 39.4°C. He has persistent conjunctival injection, cracked lips, and a new desquamating rash on his fingertips. Echocardiogram shows mild coronary artery dilation (z-score 2.8) without aneurysm. Labs show CRP 8.5 mg/dL (elevated) and platelet count 650,000/μL.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Repeat IVIG 2 g/kg infusion","label":"A"},{"text":"Initiate high-dose IV methylprednisolone","label":"B"},{"text":"Add infliximab to current regimen","label":"C"},{"text":"Continue aspirin only and observe","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat IVIG plus add IV methylprednisolone","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has IVIG-refractory Kawasaki disease, defined as persistent or recrudescent fever ≥36 hours after completing initial IVIG. Approximately 10- 20% of patients are IVIG-refractory. Addition of corticosteroids to retreatment may be considered, particularly for patients with risk factors for coronary artery aneurysms, but the primary intervention is repeat IVIG. Infliximab or other biologics are typically reserved for patients who fail second-line therapy or have high-risk features.

Distractor Analysis: (B) Initiate high-dose IV methylprednisolone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Add infliximab to current regimen: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Continue aspirin only and observe: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Repeat IVIG plus add IV methylprednisolone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: IVIG-refractory Kawasaki disease (persistent fever ≥36 hours after initial IVIG) is first managed with a second dose of IVIG; escalation to steroids or infliximab follows if refractory persists.

stem:
A 62-year-old man from an endemic region is found to have a positive interferon-gamma release assay during routine screening prior to starting adalimumab for rheumatoid arthritis. Chest X-ray is normal. He has no symptoms of active tuberculosis. He has a history of isoniazid-related hepatotoxicity during a prior incomplete treatment attempt 10 years ago (ALT rose to 8 times the upper limit of normal). His current liver function tests are normal.

What is the most appropriate treatment for latent tuberculosis infection?
options: [{"text":"Isoniazid 300 mg daily for 9 months with hepatic monitoring","label":"A"},{"text":"Isoniazid 300 mg plus rifapentine weekly for 12 weeks","label":"B"},{"text":"Rifampin 600 mg daily for 4 months","label":"C"},{"text":"No treatment needed given prior hepatotoxicity","label":"D"},{"text":"Delay TNF-inhibitor therapy indefinitely","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient requires latent TB infection (LTBI) treatment prior to TNF-inhibitor therapy due to high reactivation risk. However, he has a documented history of significant isoniazid-induced hepatotoxicity, which precludes re-challenge with isoniazid-containing regimens. Rifampin monotherapy for 4 months is an effective alternative with a better hepatic safety profile than isoniazid. It is particularly appropriate in patients with prior isoniazid intolerance, those at risk for hepatotoxicity, or when adherence to longer regimens is a concern.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Isoniazid 300 mg daily for 9 months with hepatic monitoring: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Isoniazid 300 mg plus rifapentine weekly for 12 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) No treatment needed given prior hepatotoxicity: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Delay TNF-inhibitor therapy indefinitely: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: NEUROLOGY & PSYCHIATRY

stem:
A 28-year-old woman with known systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with 2 weeks of facial swelling and foamy urine. She is currently on hydroxychloroquine only. Labs reveal creatinine 1.6 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL), urine protein-to-creatinine ratio of 4.2 g/g, and urine microscopy shows numerous RBC casts. C3 and C4 are low, and anti-dsDNA antibody titers have risen four-fold. She is hemodynamically stable but increasingly edematous. Nephrology consultation for renal biopsy has a 10-day wait due to scheduling constraints.

What is the most appropriate management while awaiting biopsy?
options: [{"text":"Wait for biopsy results before initiating any immunosuppressive therapy","label":"A"},{"text":"Start high-dose prednisone now and await biopsy for further decisions","label":"B"},{"text":"Start hydroxychloroquine dose increase only","label":"C"},{"text":"Initiate both high-dose corticosteroids and mycophenolate empirically","label":"D"},{"text":"Proceed with cyclophosphamide induction empirically","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has active lupus nephritis based on nephrotic-range proteinuria, rising creatinine, active urine sediment (RBC casts), and serologic activity (low complements, rising anti-dsDNA). Renal biopsy remains essential for classification and guiding long-term therapy, but when biopsy is delayed and there is clear evidence of active nephritis, initiating high-dose corticosteroids empirically is appropriate. Steroids provide immediate anti-inflammatory effect and can be safely started while awaiting histologic classification. The addition of specific steroid-sparing agents (mycophenolate vs.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Wait for biopsy results before initiating any immunosuppress...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Start hydroxychloroquine dose increase only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Initiate both high-dose corticosteroids and mycophenolate em...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Proceed with cyclophosphamide induction empirically: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: INFECTIOUS DISEASE

stem:
A 34-year-old woman with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis presents with acute right-sided weakness and difficulty walking, progressing over 3 days. MRI brain shows a new enhancing lesion in the left periventricular white matter. She receives high-dose IV methylprednisolone (1g daily) for 5 days but shows no improvement 10 days after completing the course. She cannot ambulate without assistance, and repeat MRI shows persistent enhancement. She has not responded to oral prednisone taper initiated after IV steroids.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Repeat 5-day course of IV methylprednisolone","label":"A"},{"text":"Initiate plasma exchange (plasmapheresis)","label":"B"},{"text":"Start natalizumab immediately","label":"C"},{"text":"Transition to cyclophosphamide pulse therapy","label":"D"},{"text":"Observe for spontaneous improvement over the next 4 weeks","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has a steroid-refractory MS relapse, defined as lack of meaningful clinical improvement after high-dose IV corticosteroids. Plasma exchange (plasmapheresis or PLEX) is the established second-line treatment for severe, disabling MS relapses that fail to respond to corticosteroids. PLEX removes circulating autoantibodies and inflammatory mediators and has been shown to produce improvement in approximately 40-50% of steroid-refractory patients. It is typically administered as 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Repeat 5-day course of IV methylprednisolone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Start natalizumab immediately: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Transition to cyclophosphamide pulse therapy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Observe for spontaneous improvement over the next 4 weeks: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Steroid-refractory MS relapse with significant disability warrants plasma exchange as the next step, not repeat steroids or disease-modifying therapy initiation.

stem:
A 52-year-old man with recently diagnosed membranous nephropathy is being managed with immunosuppressive therapy. Labs show serum albumin of 1.8 g/dL, urine protein-to-creatinine ratio of 11 g/g, and creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL. He has no personal or family history of thromboembolism. He is not immobilized and has no other prothrombotic conditions. Renal biopsy confirmed primary membranous nephropathy with PLA2R antibody positivity.

What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding anticoagulation?
options: [{"text":"No anticoagulation needed unless thrombosis occurs","label":"A"},{"text":"Low-dose aspirin 81 mg daily for prophylaxis","label":"B"},{"text":"Prophylactic anticoagulation with apixaban or warfarin","label":"C"},{"text":"Anticoagulation only if antithrombin III level is low","label":"D"},{"text":"Compression stockings and early ambulation only","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Membranous nephropathy carries the highest thrombotic risk among nephrotic syndrome etiologies, with venous thromboembolism occurring in 20- 30% of patients. The degree of hypoalbuminemia correlates with thrombotic risk, and albumin <2.5-2.8 g/dL is commonly used as a threshold for prophylactic anticoagulation, particularly in membranous nephropathy. This patient's albumin of 1.8 g/dL places him in a high-risk category. The mechanism involves urinary loss of antithrombin III, protein C, and protein S, along with increased hepatic synthesis of procoagulant factors.

Distractor Analysis: (A) No anticoagulation needed unless thrombosis occurs: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Low-dose aspirin 81 mg daily for prophylaxis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Anticoagulation only if antithrombin III level is low: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Compression stockings and early ambulation only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: ENDOCRINOLOGY

stem:
A 42-year-old man with schizophrenia and comorbid depression is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status, temperature of 39.8°C, diaphoresis, and generalized tremor. He was recently started on haloperidol 2 weeks ago for psychotic exacerbation and fluoxetine 3 days ago for worsening depression. On examination, he has marked muscle rigidity (lead-pipe type), hyperreflexia, bilateral ankle clonus, and dilated pupils. Vital signs show HR 118 bpm, BP 162/98 mmHg. Labs show WBC 14,000/μL and CK 2,400 U/L.

Which clinical feature most reliably distinguishes between the two most likely diagnoses?
options: [{"text":"Elevated temperature","label":"A"},{"text":"Presence of tremor","label":"B"},{"text":"Elevated creatine kinase","label":"C"},{"text":"Hyperreflexia with clonus","label":"D"},{"text":"Muscle rigidity","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has features overlapping between neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) from haloperidol and serotonin syndrome from fluoxetine. Both can cause hyperthermia, altered mental status, autonomic instability, and elevated CK. The distinguishing feature is the neurologic examination: NMS causes lead-pipe rigidity with bradyreflexia or normal reflexes (extrapyramidal/dopaminergic), while serotonin syndrome causes hyperreflexia, clonus, and myoclonus (serotonergic neuromuscular excitation). This patient's hyperreflexia and ankle clonus point toward serotonin syndrome or a mixed picture, despite the rigidity suggesting NMS.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Elevated temperature: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Presence of tremor: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Elevated creatine kinase: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Muscle rigidity: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: OB/GYN

stem:
A 45-year-old woman with no significant past medical history undergoes CT pulmonary angiography for evaluation of pleuritic chest pain following a 6- hour car ride. The scan reveals a single subsegmental pulmonary embolism in the right lower lobe without evidence of right heart strain. She has no tachycardia, hypoxia, or hemodynamic instability. D-dimer is mildly elevated at 0.8 μg/mL. Lower extremity duplex ultrasound shows no deep vein thrombosis. She has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and is otherwise healthy.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Therapeutic anticoagulation with rivaroxaban for 3 months","label":"A"},{"text":"Therapeutic anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin for 3 months","label":"B"},{"text":"Inferior vena cava filter placement","label":"C"},{"text":"Clinical surveillance without anticoagulation","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat CT pulmonary angiography in 48-72 hours","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Isolated subsegmental pulmonary embolism (SSPE) in a low-risk patient without proximal DVT represents a clinical scenario where the risk-benefit ratio of anticoagulation is uncertain. Per current guidelines, clinical surveillance without anticoagulation is a reasonable option for patients with SSPE who have low risk of recurrence (no ongoing risk factors), no proximal DVT on bilateral leg imaging, low cardiopulmonary reserve is not compromised, and no symptoms requiring treatment. This patient's minor provocation (short car ride), absence of DVT, hemodynamic stability, and bleeding risk (menorrhagia) favor observation. The false-positive rate of CT for subsegmental clots is non-trivial, and anticoagulating all SSPEs leads to unnecessary bleeding complications.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Therapeutic anticoagulation with rivaroxaban for 3 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Therapeutic anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight hepari...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Inferior vena cava filter placement: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Repeat CT pulmonary angiography in 48-72 hours: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Isolated subsegmental PE without proximal DVT in a low-risk, hemodynamically stable patient can be managed with clinical surveillance rather than anticoagulation.

stem:
A 32-year-old man was diagnosed with acute viral pericarditis 10 days ago and started on ibuprofen 600 mg three times daily. He initially improved but returns with recurrent sharp pleuritic chest pain that worsens with inspiration and lying flat. Temperature is 37.8°C, and a pericardial friction rub is present. ECG shows diffuse ST elevations with PR depression. Echocardiogram reveals a trivial pericardial effusion without tamponade physiology. He has been adherent to ibuprofen and denies NSAID intolerance.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Increase ibuprofen to 800 mg three times daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Add colchicine 0.5 mg twice daily","label":"B"},{"text":"Switch to prednisone 0.5 mg/kg daily","label":"C"},{"text":"Add colchicine and prednisone simultaneously","label":"D"},{"text":"Obtain pericardiocentesis for diagnostic evaluation","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has NSAID-refractory acute pericarditis, defined as persistent or recurrent symptoms despite adequate NSAID therapy. The appropriate escalation is to add colchicine to the existing NSAID regimen, not to switch therapies. Colchicine works synergistically with NSAIDs by inhibiting microtubule assembly in inflammatory cells and has been shown in the COPE and ICAP trials to reduce recurrence rates from ~30% to ~15%.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Increase ibuprofen to 800 mg three times daily: He is already on therapeutic dosing (600 mg TID = 1800 mg/day); the issue is mechanism of resistance, not dose inadequacy. Higher doses increase GI bleeding risk without addressing refractory inflammation. (C) Switch to prednisone 0.5 mg/kg daily: Corticosteroids should be avoided in acute pericarditis as first-line escalation because they paradoxically increase recurrence risk and prolong disease course. They are reserved for contraindications to NSAIDs/colchicine or autoimmune etiologies. (D) Add colchicine and prednisone simultaneously: Adding steroids when colchicine alone would suffice increases recurrence risk and causes unnecessary steroid side effects. The correct approach is stepwise escalation. (E) Obtain pericardiocentesis for diagnostic evaluation: Pericardiocentesis is indicated for cardiac tamponade or suspected purulent pericarditis; this patient has a trivial effusion without tamponade, making drainage unnecessary and potentially harmful.

Clinical Pearl: When acute pericarditis fails to respond to NSAIDs alone, add colchicine rather than switching to or adding corticosteroids, which increase recurrence risk.

stem:
A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 31 weeks gestation presents with spontaneous rupture of membranes confirmed by nitrazine and ferning tests. She is afebrile, non-contracting, and fetal heart tracing is category I. Group B streptococcus status is unknown. She receives antenatal corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity. Latency antibiotics are initiated per protocol.

What is the appropriate duration of latency antibiotic therapy?
options: [{"text":"48 hours only","label":"A"},{"text":"Until delivery occurs","label":"B"},{"text":"7 days regardless of delivery timing","label":"C"},{"text":"10 days with oral agent completion at home","label":"D"},{"text":"Until GBS culture results return","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: In preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), latency antibiotics are administered to prolong pregnancy and reduce infectious complications. The standard regimen is 7 days total: typically 48 hours of IV ampicillin and erythromycin (or azithromycin) followed by 5 days of oral amoxicillin and erythromycin (or azithromycin alone for 5 days after IV). This regimen has been shown to prolong latency, reduce chorioamnionitis, and improve neonatal outcomes. The duration is 7 days total, not until delivery or based on culture results.

Distractor Analysis: (A) 48 hours only: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Until delivery occurs: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) 10 days with oral agent completion at home: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Until GBS culture results return: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Latency antibiotics in PPROM are administered for 7 days total (not until delivery) to prolong pregnancy and reduce infection.

stem:
A 54-year-old man undergoes EGD for epigastric pain revealing a 1.2-cm duodenal ulcer without active bleeding. He denies NSAID or aspirin use and drinks alcohol socially. Biopsies are obtained, and he is started on a proton pump inhibitor. Histopathology returns negative for Helicobacter pylori on hematoxylin and eosin stain and special stains. He was taking omeprazole for 3 weeks prior to the EGD prescribed by another provider. Stool antigen for H. pylori is also negative (obtained while on PPI). Serology for H. pylori IgG is positive.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Continue PPI monotherapy with no further H. pylori workup","label":"A"},{"text":"Treat for H. pylori infection with triple therapy","label":"B"},{"text":"Repeat EGD with biopsy after 4 weeks off PPI","label":"C"},{"text":"Obtain urea breath test after 4 weeks off PPI","label":"D"},{"text":"Consider the patient H. pylori negative and evaluate for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has duodenal ulcer disease with discordant H. pylori testing—negative histology and stool antigen but positive serology. PPIs significantly reduce H. pylori bacterial load and urease activity, leading to false-negative results on urease-based tests (stool antigen, urea breath test) and histology.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue PPI monotherapy with no further H. pylori workup: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Repeat EGD with biopsy after 4 weeks off PPI: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Obtain urea breath test after 4 weeks off PPI: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Consider the patient H. pylori negative and evaluate for Zol...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: pylori testing on histology and stool antigen in a patient on PPI therapy does not exclude infection; positive serology with duodenal ulcer warrants empiric treatment.

stem:
A 5-week-old male infant presents with 5 days of progressively forceful, non-bilious vomiting occurring after every feed. He appears dehydrated with a sunken fontanelle and dry mucous membranes. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable "olive" in the epigastrium. Labs show sodium 132 mEq/L, potassium 2.8 mEq/L, chloride 88 mEq/L, bicarbonate 34 mEq/L, and pH 7.52. Abdominal ultrasound confirms pyloric stenosis.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: [{"text":"Emergent pyloromyotomy within 2 hours","label":"A"},{"text":"IV fluid resuscitation with correction of electrolyte abnormalities, then surgery","label":"B"},{"text":"Nasogastric tube decompression and trial of prokinetic agents","label":"C"},{"text":"Atropine therapy to relax the pylorus","label":"D"},{"text":"Immediate surgical consultation for pyloromyotomy today","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Pyloric stenosis causes hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric hydrochloric acid through vomiting. While pyloromyotomy is the definitive treatment, it is not a surgical emergency. Operating on a significantly alkalotic infant increases anesthetic risk, particularly post-operative apnea, because metabolic alkalosis causes compensatory hypoventilation that may not recover quickly after anesthesia. The priority is to resuscitate with IV normal saline (with potassium supplementation once urinating) to correct dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Emergent pyloromyotomy within 2 hours: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Nasogastric tube decompression and trial of prokinetic agent...: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Atropine therapy to relax the pylorus: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Immediate surgical consultation for pyloromyotomy today: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Pyloric stenosis requires metabolic correction (alkalosis, hypokalemia, dehydration) before pyloromyotomy; surgery is not emergent and carries increased risk in uncorrected alkalotic infants.

stem:
A 29-year-old woman at 8 weeks gestation presents for her first prenatal visit. She has no history of thyroid disease. Routine thyroid screening shows TSH of 4.8 mIU/L (pregnancy-specific reference range: 0.1-2.5 mIU/L for first trimester), free T4 of 1.1 ng/dL (normal), and TPO antibodies are negative. She is asymptomatic and has no goiter on exam. Her pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"No treatment needed as free T4 is normal","label":"A"},{"text":"Repeat thyroid function tests in the second trimester","label":"B"},{"text":"Initiate levothyroxine therapy","label":"C"},{"text":"Recheck TSH after iodine supplementation","label":"D"},{"text":"Observe and treat only if TSH exceeds 10 mIU/L","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Pregnancy fundamentally changes the TSH threshold for treatment of hypothyroidism. In the first trimester, fetal neurodevelopment depends entirely on maternal thyroid hormone, and the upper limit of normal for TSH is reduced (typically 2.5-4.0 mIU/L depending on the assay and population). This patient has subclinical hypothyroidism by pregnancy-specific criteria (elevated TSH with normal free T4). The American Thyroid Association recommends treatment with levothyroxine for pregnant women with TSH above the trimester-specific reference range.

Distractor Analysis: (A) No treatment needed as free T4 is normal: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Repeat thyroid function tests in the second trimester: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Recheck TSH after iodine supplementation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Observe and treat only if TSH exceeds 10 mIU/L: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: In pregnancy, TSH above the trimester-specific reference range (typically >2.5-4.0 mIU/L in first trimester) warrants levothyroxine, even if free T4 is normal.

stem:
A 68-year-old woman on warfarin for atrial fibrillation presents for routine INR monitoring. She is asymptomatic with no signs of bleeding—no bruising, hematuria, melena, or epistaxis. Her INR is 5.8 (target 2-3). She took an extra warfarin dose by mistake 3 days ago. Physical examination is unremarkable. Complete blood count shows hemoglobin of 12.4 g/dL (baseline 12.6 g/dL). She is at low risk for falls and has no history of major bleeding.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Administer vitamin K 2.5 mg orally","label":"A"},{"text":"Administer vitamin K 10 mg IV","label":"B"},{"text":"Hold warfarin and recheck INR in 24-48 hours","label":"C"},{"text":"Hold warfarin and administer fresh frozen plasma","label":"D"},{"text":"Continue warfarin at current dose and recheck INR in 1 week","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: For asymptomatic supratherapeutic INR between 4.5-10 without bleeding, the recommended management is to hold warfarin and monitor. Vitamin K is not routinely indicated unless INR is >10 or the patient is bleeding or at high bleeding risk. This patient's INR of 5.8 with no bleeding, stable hemoglobin, and clear explanation (accidental extra dose) can be managed conservatively. The half-life of warfarin means INR will drift down over 24-48 hours simply by holding doses.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Administer vitamin K 2.5 mg orally: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Administer vitamin K 10 mg IV: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Hold warfarin and administer fresh frozen plasma: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Continue warfarin at current dose and recheck INR in 1 week: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: RHEUMATOLOGY

stem:
A 58-year-old woman undergoes CT chest for lung cancer staging. Imaging reveals a subsegmental pulmonary embolism in a peripheral branch of the right lower lobe. She is asymptomatic with normal vital signs, oxygen saturation 98% on room air, and no leg swelling. Her cancer is limited to a 1.5 cm nodule without lymph node involvement.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Start therapeutic anticoagulation with apixaban","label":"A"},{"text":"Obtain lower extremity duplex ultrasound","label":"B"},{"text":"Place inferior vena cava filter","label":"C"},{"text":"Repeat CT pulmonary angiography in 48 hours","label":"D"},{"text":"Clinical surveillance without anticoagulation","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Incidental subsegmental PE in asymptomatic patients—particularly those with isolated peripheral clots and no concomitant DVT—represents a gray zone where anticoagulation may cause more harm than benefit. The 2019 ASH guidelines acknowledge that subsegmental PE without proximal DVT in low-risk, asymptomatic patients may be observed. This patient has no symptoms, stable vitals, adequate oxygenation, and limited-stage cancer. The bleeding risk of anticoagulation may outweigh benefit.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Start therapeutic anticoagulation with apixaban: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Obtain lower extremity duplex ultrasound: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Place inferior vena cava filter: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Repeat CT pulmonary angiography in 48 hours: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Surveillance with close follow-up is reasonable.

stem:
A 72-year-old man with COPD undergoes CT angiography for evaluation of a thoracic aortic aneurysm. An incidental filling defect is noted in a subsegmental artery of the left lower lobe. He denies dyspnea, chest pain, or leg swelling. Vital signs: BP 128/76, HR 72, RR 14, SpO2 95% on room air. Lower extremity ultrasound shows no DVT.

Which factor most supports observation rather than anticoagulation?
options: [{"text":"History of COPD","label":"A"},{"text":"Subsegmental location without DVT","label":"B"},{"text":"Age greater than 70","label":"C"},{"text":"Thoracic aortic aneurysm","label":"D"},{"text":"SpO2 of 95%","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: When clot burden is minimal and there is no evidence of propagation from the deep venous system, the clinical significance is uncertain. Guidelines suggest that in asymptomatic patients without DVT, the risk-benefit ratio of anticoagulation shifts toward observation. COPD, age, and baseline SpO2 are not the primary factors driving this decision.

Distractor Analysis: (A) History of COPD: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Age greater than 70: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Thoracic aortic aneurysm: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) SpO2 of 95%: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: COPD, age, and baseline SpO2 are not the primary factors driving this decision.

stem:
A 55-year-old woman undergoes abdominal ultrasound for elevated liver enzymes, revealing three gallstones (largest 1.2 cm) with normal gallbladder wall thickness and no biliary dilation. Liver enzymes normalize on repeat testing. She has never had abdominal pain, and the stones were incidentally discovered.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy","label":"A"},{"text":"Ursodiol for gallstone dissolution","label":"B"},{"text":"MRCP to evaluate for choledocholithiasis","label":"C"},{"text":"Observation without intervention","label":"D"},{"text":"ERCP with sphincterotomy","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Asymptomatic gallstones are common (10-15% of adults) and the majority never cause symptoms. Prophylactic cholecystectomy for incidental stones is not recommended—the surgical risk exceeds the low likelihood (~1-2%/year) of developing symptoms. Ursodiol is only effective for small cholesterol stones and is not indicated for asymptomatic stones. MRCP/ERCP are not warranted without clinical concern for CBD stones.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Ursodiol for gallstone dissolution: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) MRCP to evaluate for choledocholithiasis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) ERCP with sphincterotomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Observation with patient education about biliary colic symptoms (postprandial RUQ pain, especially after fatty meals) is appropriate.

stem:
A 48-year-old man with asymptomatic gallstones discovered 2 years ago presents after one episode of postprandial right upper quadrant pain lasting 45 minutes that resolved spontaneously. He is currently pain-free. Ultrasound shows stones without gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Continue observation","label":"A"},{"text":"Elective cholecystectomy","label":"B"},{"text":"Admit for IV antibiotics","label":"C"},{"text":"HIDA scan","label":"D"},{"text":"Low-fat diet alone","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Once gallstones become symptomatic (biliary colic), the risk of recurrent episodes and complications (cholecystitis, pancreatitis, choledocholithiasis) increases substantially. Unlike asymptomatic stones, symptomatic gallstones warrant elective cholecystectomy. This patient had a classic biliary colic episode—postprandial pain lasting <6 hours that resolved. He does not have acute cholecystitis (no fever, wall thickening, or ongoing symptoms), so admission is unnecessary.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue observation: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Admit for IV antibiotics: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) HIDA scan: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Low-fat diet alone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Dietary modification alone does not prevent recurrence or complications.

stem:
A 58-year-old man presents with left lower quadrant pain for 2 days. CT shows sigmoid diverticulosis with mild pericolic fat stranding but no abscess, perforation, or obstruction. He is afebrile, tolerating oral intake, and has normal WBC. He has no immunocompromise.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Admit for IV antibiotics","label":"A"},{"text":"Outpatient oral antibiotics for 7-10 days","label":"B"},{"text":"Supportive care without antibiotics","label":"C"},{"text":"Surgical consultation for sigmoid resection","label":"D"},{"text":"Colonoscopy during this admission","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Multiple RCTs (AVOD, DIABOLO) demonstrate that uncomplicated diverticulitis in immunocompetent patients can be managed without antibiotics. Uncomplicated = no abscess, fistula, obstruction, or perforation. This patient has mild CT findings, no systemic illness, and can tolerate oral intake. Supportive care (clear liquids advancing to regular diet, analgesia) is sufficient.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Admit for IV antibiotics: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Outpatient oral antibiotics for 7-10 days: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Surgical consultation for sigmoid resection: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Colonoscopy during this admission: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Colonoscopy should be performed 6-8 weeks after resolution to exclude malignancy, not during acute inflammation.

stem:
A 64-year-old woman with diabetes presents with LLQ pain, fever (101.5°F), and WBC 14,500. CT shows diverticulitis with a 2.5 cm pericolic abscess.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Outpatient oral antibiotics","label":"A"},{"text":"Admit for IV antibiotics and possible percutaneous drainage","label":"B"},{"text":"Supportive care without antibiotics","label":"C"},{"text":"Emergent sigmoid colectomy","label":"D"},{"text":"Colonoscopy to rule out malignancy","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has complicated diverticulitis (abscess) plus systemic signs (fever, leukocytosis) and diabetes (relative immunocompromise). This requires IV antibiotics and likely percutaneous drainage for abscesses >3 cm (2.5 cm is borderline—may resolve with antibiotics alone or require drainage if not improving). The no-antibiotic approach applies only to uncomplicated disease in immunocompetent patients. Emergent surgery is reserved for perforation with peritonitis, not contained abscess.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Outpatient oral antibiotics: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Supportive care without antibiotics: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Emergent sigmoid colectomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Colonoscopy to rule out malignancy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Colonoscopy is deferred until inflammation resolves.

stem:
A 45-year-old woman with BMI 31 has fasting glucose of 112 mg/dL and HbA1c of 5.9% on annual screening. She has no other cardiovascular risk factors. She exercises occasionally and has a diet high in processed foods.

What is the most appropriate initial intervention?
options: [{"text":"Metformin 500 mg twice daily","label":"A"},{"text":"Intensive lifestyle modification program","label":"B"},{"text":"GLP-1 receptor agonist","label":"C"},{"text":"SGLT2 inhibitor","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat testing in 1 year without intervention","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: This patient has prediabetes (FG 100-125 or A1c 5.7-6.4%). The Diabetes Prevention Program demonstrated that intensive lifestyle intervention (7% weight loss goal, 150 min/week moderate activity) reduces diabetes incidence by 58%—superior to metformin (31% reduction). Metformin is an option for high-risk patients (BMI ≥35, age <60, prior GDM, rising A1c) but is second-line to lifestyle. This patient's risk profile supports starting with lifestyle intervention before pharmacotherapy.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Metformin 500 mg twice daily: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) GLP-1 receptor agonist: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) SGLT2 inhibitor: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Repeat testing in 1 year without intervention: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: ADA guidelines recommend lifestyle modification as first-line for prediabetes.

stem:
A 52-year-old man with BMI 38, prediabetes (A1c 6.3%), and family history of T2DM in both parents has been unable to lose weight despite 6 months of dietary counseling. He has tried structured exercise programs without success.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"Continue lifestyle counseling alone","label":"A"},{"text":"Add metformin","label":"B"},{"text":"Refer for bariatric surgery","label":"C"},{"text":"Start empagliflozin","label":"D"},{"text":"Accept prediabetes as a stable condition","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: After lifestyle intervention fails or in high-risk prediabetics (BMI ≥35, age <60, history of GDM, strong family history), metformin is appropriate per ADA guidelines. This patient has multiple high-risk features: severe obesity, A1c at upper prediabetic range, and bilateral parental diabetes history. Metformin modestly reduces progression to diabetes. While bariatric surgery is highly effective, it is typically reserved for BMI ≥40 or ≥35 with comorbidities—and metformin should be tried first.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Continue lifestyle counseling alone: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Refer for bariatric surgery: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Start empagliflozin: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Accept prediabetes as a stable condition: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: SGLT2 inhibitors are not FDA-approved for prediabetes prevention.

stem:
A 17-year-old male is noted to have a left-sided varicocele during a sports physical. It is palpable only during Valsalva (Grade I). Both testes are symmetric in size. He is asymptomatic and has no interest in fertility evaluation at this time.

What is the most appropriate management?
options: [{"text":"Surgical varicocelectomy","label":"A"},{"text":"Scrotal ultrasound with Doppler","label":"B"},{"text":"Semen analysis","label":"C"},{"text":"Annual observation with testicular size measurement","label":"D"},{"text":"Interventional radiology embolization","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Grade I varicoceles (palpable only with Valsalva) in adolescents are common and usually benign. Intervention is indicated for: testicular hypotrophy (>20% size differential or >2 mL volume difference), pain, or abnormal semen analysis in adults. This patient has symmetric testes and no symptoms. Annual monitoring to detect testicular growth arrest is appropriate.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Surgical varicocelectomy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) Scrotal ultrasound with Doppler: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Semen analysis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Interventional radiology embolization: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Treatment for asymptomatic, low-grade varicoceles without hypotrophy constitutes overtreatment.

stem:
A 24-year-old man presents for infertility evaluation after 1 year of unprotected intercourse. Exam reveals a Grade II left varicocele. Semen analysis shows oligoasthenospermia (count 8 million/mL, 25% motility). Right testis is normal size; left is slightly smaller.

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"Observation and repeat semen analysis in 6 months","label":"A"},{"text":"Surgical varicocelectomy","label":"B"},{"text":"Intrauterine insemination without surgical correction","label":"C"},{"text":"Clomiphene citrate","label":"D"},{"text":"Reassurance that varicocele is unrelated to infertility","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Varicocelectomy is indicated in men with clinical varicocele + abnormal semen parameters + infertility (when female partner is normal or has treatable causes). This patient meets all criteria. Repair improves semen parameters in 60-70% of men and pregnancy rates increase. Observation would delay treatment for a correctable cause.

Distractor Analysis: (A) Observation and repeat semen analysis in 6 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Intrauterine insemination without surgical correction: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Clomiphene citrate: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Reassurance that varicocele is unrelated to infertility: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: The combination of palpable varicocele, ipsilateral testicular hypotrophy, and abnormal semen analysis strongly supports surgical intervention as the next step.

stem:
A 42-year-old woman undergoes abdominal ultrasound for dyspepsia, which reveals a 2.5 cm hyperechoic lesion in the right hepatic lobe with characteristic features of hemangioma. She has no liver disease risk factors, normal liver enzymes, and no malignancy history.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"MRI liver with contrast to confirm diagnosis","label":"A"},{"text":"CT abdomen with contrast","label":"B"},{"text":"Percutaneous liver biopsy","label":"C"},{"text":"Reassurance with no further imaging","label":"D"},{"text":"Repeat ultrasound in 6 months","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Hepatic hemangiomas are the most common benign liver tumors. When ultrasound shows classic features (well-defined, hyperechoic, homogeneous lesion) in a patient without malignancy history or liver disease, no further imaging is required. Hemangiomas do not undergo malignant transformation and rarely cause symptoms unless very large (>10 cm). Confirmatory MRI is unnecessary for typical-appearing lesions.

Distractor Analysis: (A) MRI liver with contrast to confirm diagnosis: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (B) CT abdomen with contrast: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) Percutaneous liver biopsy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Repeat ultrasound in 6 months: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Surveillance imaging adds cost and anxiety without changing management.

stem:
A 55-year-old man with history of colon cancer treated 3 years ago has a 3 cm liver lesion found on surveillance CT. The lesion shows peripheral nodular enhancement with centripetal fill-in—classic for hemangioma.

What is the most appropriate next step?
options: [{"text":"No further workup needed","label":"A"},{"text":"MRI liver with hepatobiliary contrast","label":"B"},{"text":"PET-CT","label":"C"},{"text":"Percutaneous biopsy","label":"D"},{"text":"Surgical resection","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: In patients with prior malignancy, even classic-appearing hemangiomas warrant confirmatory imaging because hepatic metastases can occasionally mimic hemangiomas. MRI with hepatobiliary contrast (gadoxetate) has high specificity for distinguishing hemangioma from metastases. This differs from the prior question because cancer history changes the pretest probability of malignancy. If MRI confirms hemangioma, no further workup is needed.

Distractor Analysis: (A) No further workup needed: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (C) PET-CT: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (D) Percutaneous biopsy: Incorrect for this clinical scenario. (E) Surgical resection: Incorrect for this clinical scenario.

Clinical Pearl: Update Todos Generate questions for concepts 1-7 Generate questions for concepts 8-14 Generating questions for concepts 15-21

stem:
A 60-year-old man has an incidental 3 cm left renal cyst found on CT for kidney stone evaluation. The cyst is homogeneous, water-attenuation, with a thin wall and no septations, calcifications, or enhancement (Bosniak I).

What is the most appropriate recommendation?
options: [{"text":"MRI for further characterization","label":"A"},{"text":"Percutaneous aspiration and cytology","label":"B"},{"text":"Repeat CT in 6 months","label":"C"},{"text":"No follow-up imaging required","label":"D"},{"text":"Urologic referral for cyst decortication","label":"E"}]
explanation:
Pathophysiology: Bosniak I cysts are simple cysts with essentially 0% malignancy risk. They have thin walls, no septations, no calcification, and do not enhance. No follow-up is needed—these are benign findings that do not warrant surveillance. Imaging or intervention would constitute unnecessary healthcare utilization.
